Question_11.Context: Alkaline hydrogen peroxide (AHP) treatment is used to enhance the digestibility of lignocellulosic biomass by removing lignin and other components that limit enzyme access to cellulose.
Question_11.Question: What is the primary purpose of using alkaline hydrogen peroxide (AHP) treatment on lignocellulosic biomass?
Question_11.Source: The optimization of AHP treatment is a key step to minimize the cost of treatment without increasing both polyphenols content and lipid oxidation. In this regard, AHP treatment of EOP was investigated using the response surface methodology RSM in which sodium hydroxide (NaOH) varied between 1% (w/v) to 6% (w/v) and hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) varied between 1% (w/v) and 4% (w/v).

related_data.Title: Effect of Alkaline Hydrogen Peroxide Pretreatment on In Vitro Rumen Digestibility of Exhausted Olive Pomace
related_data.Abstract: Due to the sharp rise in animal feed costs, funding alternatives to substitute high-cost raw materials used in animal feed is a persistent need. This study investigated the effect of alkaline hydrogen peroxide pretreatment as straightforward non-toxic technology to enhance the in vitro rumen digestibility of exhausted olive pomace (EOP), an abundant agricultural waste, to be suitable as animal feedstock. It examined the efficiency to eliminate the toxic phenolic content and minimize lipid oxidation of EOP.
related_data.Institute of Origin: University of Carthage, Tunisia
related_data.Funding: Tunisian Ministry of Higher Education and Scientific Research—University of Carthage (Tunisia)
related_data.Methods: The study optimized the alkaline hydrogen peroxide treatment using a central composite experimental design. The phenolic content and lipid oxidation were chosen as model responses to assess the treatment efficiency. Chemical composition analysis, enzymatic hydrolysis, and in vitro rumen fermentation assays were conducted to evaluate the effectiveness of the treatment.
related_data.Results: The optimized conditions for AHP treatment were found to be 5% NaOH and 1.6% H2O2, resulting in a significant reduction in phenolic content and lipid oxidation of the olive pomace. The treated olive pomace showed improved in vitro rumen digestibility, higher gas production, and metabolizable energy compared to untreated olive pomace.
related_data.Experiment details: The study demonstrated that alkaline hydrogen peroxide treatment can effectively detoxify and enhance the in vitro rumen digestibility of olive pomace, making it a potential high-quality animal feedstuff. The results suggest a sustainable transformation method for valorizing this agricultural waste.

related_data.Title: Producing Butyric Acid from Pre-Treated Rape Straw Using Simultaneous Enzymatic Hydrolysis Semi-Solid Fermentation
related_data.Abstract: Butyric acid is a volatile saturated monocarboxylic acid widely used in various industries. This study focuses on producing butyric acid from pre-treated rape straw using simultaneous enzymatic hydrolysis semi-solid fermentation. Clostridium beijerinckii BRM001 was used, and the genome of C. beijerinckii BRM001 was sequenced and annotated. Fermentation optimization based on genomic analysis resulted in an optimized butyric acid yield. Non-sterile SEHSF was carried out, yielding 13.42 ± 0.83 g/L in a 2.5-L fermentor, providing a new approach for butyric acid production.
related_data.Institute of Origin: Sichuan University of Science & Engineering
related_data.Funding: National Natural Science Foundation of China, Cooperation Project of Wuliangye Group Co., Ltd. and Sichuan University of Science & Engineering, Sichuan University of Science & Engineering
related_data.Methods: Genome sequencing, genome annotation, fermentation optimization, non-sterile fermentation, response surface methodology
related_data.Results: Optimized butyric acid yield of 13.42 ± 0.83 g/L in a 2.5-L fermentor, providing a new approach for butyric acid production.
related_data.Experiment details: Experiment involved producing butyric acid from pre-treated rape straw using Clostridium beijerinckii BRM001, with fermentation optimization based on genomic analysis.

Question_176.Source: Ammonium acetate ranks second, with a butyric acid yield of 5.46 ± 0.23 g/L. The effect of other nitrogen sources is poor, with butyric acid yields of less than 3 g/L. Therefore, ammonium acetate is the best inorganic nitrogen source.

related_data.Title: Producing Butyric Acid from Pre-Treated Rape Straw Using Simultaneous Enzymatic Hydrolysis Semi-Solid Fermentation
related_data.Abstract: Butyric acid is a volatile saturated monocarboxylic acid widely used in various industries. This study focuses on producing butyric acid from pre-treated rape straw using simultaneous enzymatic hydrolysis semi-solid fermentation. Clostridium beijerinckii BRM001 was used, and the genome of C. beijerinckii BRM001 was sequenced and annotated. Fermentation optimization based on genomic analysis resulted in an optimized butyric acid yield. Non-sterile SEHSF was carried out, yielding 13.42 ± 0.83 g/L in a 2.5-L fermentor, providing a new approach for butyric acid production.

Question_177.Source: The biosynthesis pathways of tryptophan and biotin were incomplete, while the biosynthesis pathways of other amino acids and vitamins were complete.

Question_221.B: They are responsible for the plant's ability to absorb water
Question_221.C: They increase the rate of photosynthesis in plants
Question_221.D: They protect the plant from herbivores
Question_221.Source: R2R3‑MYB transcription factors (TFs) are known to play a key role in regulating the expression of structural genes involved in plant flavonoid biosynthesis.

related_data.Title: Identification and Functional Analysis of GmMYB108 as a Positive Regulator of Flavonoid and Anthocyanin Biosynthesis in Soybean Flowers
related_data.Abstract: R2R3‑MYB transcription factors (TFs) play a key role in regulating the expression of structural genes involved in plant flavonoid biosynthesis. In this study, we identified GmMYB108 as a potential positive regulator of isoflavonoid production in response to ethephon treatment in soybean. RNA sequencing revealed that ethephon application led to the upregulation of 22 genes related to isoflavonoid biosynthesis in soybean plants. GmMYB108 overexpression resulted in an intense accumulation of anthocyanins and total flavonoids in transgenic Arabidopsis plants. Our results suggest that GmMYB108 is a key regulator of flavonoid and anthocyanin biosynthesis in soybean flowers.
related_data.Institute of Origin: Biological Resource Center, Korea Research Institute of Bioscience Biotechnology (KRIBB), Republic of Korea
related_data.Funding: Korea Research Institute of Bioscience and Biotechnology (KRIBB) Research Initiative Program, Next-Generation BioGreen 21 Program, Rural Development Administration, National Research Foundation of Korea (NRF)
related_data.Methods: RNA sequencing, qRT-PCR, transgenic plant generation, anthocyanin and flavonoid quantification, subcellular localization analysis
related_data.Results: Identification of GmMYB108 as a positive regulator of flavonoid and anthocyanin biosynthesis in soybean flowers. Overexpression of GmMYB108 led to increased accumulation of anthocyanins and flavonoids in transgenic Arabidopsis plants. GmMYB108 upregulated multiple genes involved in anthocyanin biosynthesis and its regulatory pathways.
related_data.Experiment details: The study focused on the identification and functional analysis of GmMYB108 in soybean flowers. The researchers performed RNA sequencing, qRT-PCR, transgenic plant generation, and various biochemical assays to elucidate the role of GmMYB108 in flavonoid and anthocyanin biosynthesis.

Question_226.Context: Flavonoid glycosyltransferases (UGTs) are involved in the glycosylation of anthocyanins during their biosynthesis.
Question_226.Question: What is the role of flavonoid glycosyltransferases (UGTs) in anthocyanin biosynthesis?
Question_226.D: They degrade anthocyanins into simpler compounds
Question_226.Source: The major transcriptional regulator of flavonoid biosynthesis in various model plant species is a ternary protein complex (MBW) consisting of MYB, a basic helix-loop-helix (bHLH), and WD40-repeat proteins. Of the four MYB protein groups, R2R3-type MYBs are primarily involved in regulating flavonoid biosynthesis in several plant species, including Arabidopsis and apple (Malus domestica).

related_data.Funding: Korea Research Institute of Bioscience and Biotechnology (KRIBB) Research Initiative Program, Next-Generation BioGreen 21 Program, Rural Development Administration, National Research Foundation of Korea (NRF)
related_data.Methods: RNA sequencing, qRT-PCR, transgenic plant generation, anthocyanin and flavonoid quantification, subcellular localization analysis
related_data.Results: Identification of GmMYB108 as a positive regulator of flavonoid and anthocyanin biosynthesis in soybean flowers. Overexpression of GmMYB108 led to increased accumulation of anthocyanins and flavonoids in transgenic Arabidopsis plants. GmMYB108 upregulated multiple genes involved in anthocyanin biosynthesis and its regulatory pathways.
related_data.Experiment details: The study focused on the identification and functional analysis of GmMYB108 in soybean flowers. The researchers performed RNA sequencing, qRT-PCR, transgenic plant generation, and various biochemical assays to elucidate the role of GmMYB108 in flavonoid and anthocyanin biosynthesis.

Question_801.Context: Incorporating organic amendments into soil is a practice that can enhance soil fertility and improve soil health. Organic amendments such as food waste and biochar are known to affect soil chemical properties.
Question_801.Question: What effect does the application of food waste and biochar typically have on soil pH?
Question_801.Source: However, the application of FW and biochar increased the soil pH, with the highest pH (8.2) observed in the combined treatment of biochar and MPs.

related_data.Title: Effects of Microplastic, Food Waste, and Biochar on Soil Properties and Lettuce Growth
related_data.Abstract: The incorporation of organic amendments, such as food waste (FW) and biochar, into soil is an established agronomic practice known for enhancing soil fertility and improving overall soil health. However, the individual and combined effects of FW and biochar on soil properties in microplastic (MP)-contaminated soil–plant systems remain poorly understood. To address this knowledge gap, we conducted a field experiment to investigate the individual and combined effects of polystyrene MPs, FW, and FW-derived biochar on soil properties and lettuce growth.
related_data.Institute of Origin: Korea University
related_data.Funding: National Research Foundation of Korea (NRF) grant funded by the Korean government (MSIT) (No. 2021R1A2C2011734)
related_data.Methods: The field experiment was conducted in Banghak-dong, Seoul, South Korea. The study area falls within the humid continental climate zone. The six treatment combinations included control, 1% MP, 5% FW, 5% biochar, 1% MP + 5% FW, and 1% MP + 5% biochar. Soil samples were collected and analyzed for various parameters including pH, electrical conductivity, available nitrogen, available phosphorus, total exchangeable cations, and soil enzyme activity.
related_data.Results: The addition of MPs did not significantly affect soil pH or electrical conductivity. FW application increased soil pH and electrical conductivity, while biochar application increased soil pH. FW addition resulted in notable increases in available nitrogen, available phosphorus, and total exchangeable cations. Soil enzyme activities were affected by the different treatments, with FW doubling acid phosphatase activity. The relative abundance of certain bacterial phyla was influenced by the treatments.
related_data.Experiment details: The study demonstrated that the coexistence of MPs with FW or biochar had limited effects on soil properties and lettuce growth, with FW and biochar serving as the primary factors in modifying soil-plant systems. Future studies should further investigate the interactions of different MPs and organic soil amendments on soil properties and crop growth under different management practices.

Question_802.Context: Electrical conductivity (EC) in soil is an important measure that can be influenced by the addition of various substances, including organic amendments.
Question_802.Question: How does the application of food waste affect soil electrical conductivity (EC)?
Question_802.C: It has no effect on EC
Question_802.Source: However, the application of FW and biochar increased the soil pH, with the highest pH (8.2) observed in the combined treatment of biochar and MPs. Despite the presence of MPs, FW application resulted in notable increases in soil electrical conductivity (EC; 2.04 dS m−1)

Question_911.Context: Plant secondary metabolites are compounds that can serve as natural antioxidants, protecting cells from oxidative stress caused by environmental factors.
Question_911.Question: Which type of plant compounds are known to protect organisms against oxidative stress?
Question_911.Source: Plant secondary metabolites can be considered natural antioxidants, and are being utilized in the production of medicines, cosmetics, foods, etc.

related_data.Title: Antioxidant Abilities of Terpenoids from Cinnamomum camphora
related_data.Abstract: Plant secondary metabolites can protect organisms against oxidative stress caused by adverse environmental conditions. Cinnamomum camphora (L.) J. Presl contains plentiful terpenoids and is subdivided into 5 chemotypes. To develop natural antioxidants using the plant terpenoids, the terpenoid composition and antioxidant abilities of methanol, ethyl acetate, n-hexane and petroleum ether extracts from linalool and eucalyptol chemotypes were investigated. The solvent effects on in vitro antioxidant activity of 8 main terpenoids were analyzed. The in vivo effects of two strong antioxidant terpenoids were evaluated. Methanol extracts contained the highest content of terpenoids, contributing to their strongest scavenging activity against free radicals. Linalool, eucalyptol, ocimene, α-pinene, D-limonene, terpinene, β-pinene, and longifolene were identified as the 8 main terpenoids. Ocimene and longifolene showed the strongest activity in scavenging DPPH and ABTS free radicals. Longifolene exhibited the strongest effect on protecting algal cells against oxidative stress. Methanol was found suitable for extracting terpenoids in natural antioxidant development.
related_data.Institute of Origin: State Key Laboratory of Subtropical Silviculture, Zhejiang A&F University, Hangzhou, China
related_data.Funding: National Natural Science Foundation of China, Basic Public Welfare Research Project of Zhejiang Province, Zhejiang Provincial Natural Science Foundation of China, etc.
related_data.Methods: The terpenoid composition and antioxidant abilities were analyzed using various solvent extracts. In vitro antioxidant activity of 8 main terpenoids was evaluated. In vivo effects of two strong antioxidant terpenoids were assessed using Chlamydomonas reinhardtii as a model organism.
related_data.Results: Methanol extracts showed the strongest antioxidant ability due to the highest terpenoid content. Ocimene and longifolene exhibited strong scavenging activity against free radicals. Longifolene showed the strongest effect in protecting algal cells against oxidative stress.
related_data.Experiment details: The study focused on investigating the antioxidant abilities of terpenoids from Cinnamomum camphora, specifically linalool and eucalyptol chemotypes. The research included analysis of terpenoid composition, in vitro antioxidant activity, and in vivo effects on Chlamydomonas reinhardtii.

Question_1001.Context: Intracellular delivery technologies are used to transport therapeutic substances into target cells, which is essential for cell therapy and regenerative medicine. These substances must traverse the plasma membrane, which can be achieved through passive or active transport mechanisms.
Question_1001.Question: Which method is NOT a membrane disruption-mediated technique for intracellular delivery?
Question_1001.Source: Membrane disruption-mediated methods designed to create mechanical fields in plasma membranes are used to form temporary pores. These include electroporation, sonoporation, and photoporation.

related_data.Title: Photoporation-Based Intracellular Delivery Using Upconversion Nanoparticles and Gold Nanoparticles
related_data.Abstract: Photoporation techniques based on plasmonic nanoparticles such as gold nanoparticles have been extensively studied for the intracellular delivery of substances via cell membrane disruption. This study employed upconversion nanoparticles to stimulate gold nanoparticles at near-infrared wavelengths, resulting in the production of posAuNP@UCNPs nanocomposites. The nanocomposites were effective for the delivery of baricitinib as a treatment for osteoarthritis in a three-dimensional osteoarthritis model. The findings suggest that posAuNP@UCNPs have great potential as a tool for non-invasive drug delivery via UCPPin.
related_data.Institute of Origin: CHA University
related_data.Funding: National Research Foundation of Korea (NRF) grants funded by the Korean Government
related_data.Methods: The study involved the synthesis of posAuNP@UCNPs nanocomposites, characterization of their physical properties, evaluation of the photoporation efficiency under different conditions, and analysis of the therapeutic efficacy for osteoarthritis treatment.
related_data.Results: The posAuNP@UCNPs nanocomposites were effective for the intracellular delivery of baricitinib in an osteoarthritis model. UCPPin was found to be more efficient than PassT for substance delivery, resulting in higher inhibition of IL-6 expression.
related_data.Experiment details: The experiment included the preparation and characterization of posAuNP@UCNPs, evaluation of UCPPin efficiency under different conditions, and comparison of therapeutic efficacy between UCPPin and PassT for intracellular delivery of baricitinib.

Question_1002.Context: Plasmonic nanoparticles like gold nanoparticles can be used to deliver substances into cells by disrupting the cell membrane. This process is facilitated by the nanoparticles' ability to generate heat and form vapor nanobubbles when irradiated with light, creating transient pores in the plasma membrane.
Question_1002.Question: What is the primary reason gold nanoparticles are used in photoporation studies?
Question_1002.B: They generate heat upon light irradiation
Question_1002.D: They are visible under a microscope
Question_1002.Source: During photoporation, the vibration of AuNPs generates heat in a localized area. The high thermal conductivity of AuNPs allows for an instantaneous temperature rise, and a vapor nanobubble is formed.

Question_1003.Context: Upconversion nanoparticles (UCNPs) have the ability to absorb light at one wavelength and emit it at a shorter wavelength, a process known as anti-Stokes emission. This property is utilized in various applications including bioimaging and therapy.
Question_1003.Question: What is the process called when upconversion nanoparticles absorb light at a longer wavelength and emit it at a shorter wavelength?
Question_1003.Source: Upconversion nanoparticles (UCNPs) absorb light in the NIR wavelength band and emit visible light. Unlike photoluminescence, which has a general Stokes reaction (λex < λem), the anti-Stokes (λex > λem) reaction results in upconverting photons.

Question_1004.Context: Nanocomposites can be synthesized by combining different types of nanoparticles, such as gold nanoparticles and upconversion nanoparticles, to create new materials with unique properties suitable for specific applications.
Question_1004.Question: What is the purpose of combining gold nanoparticles with upconversion nanoparticles to create nanocomposites?
Question_1004.B: To enhance absorption in the NIR region
Question_1004.C: To reduce the overall size of the nanoparticles
Question_1004.D: To make them glow in the dark
Question_1004.Source: To overcome this challenge, upconversion nanoparticles were employed to stimulate AuNP at NIR wavelengths. posAuNP@UCNPs nanocomposites were produced by coating 30 nm UCNPs on 80 nm AuNPs.

Question_1005.Context: The zeta potential of nanoparticles is a measure of their surface charge, which influences their stability in suspension and their interaction with biological membranes.
Question_1005.Question: Why is a positive zeta potential important for nanoparticles used in photoporation?
Question_1005.C: It improves interaction with negatively charged cell membranes
Question_1005.Source: Determining the zeta potential of a particle is an important factor in photoporation efficiency, as the process is more effective with cationic particles than anionic particles.

Question_1006.Context: The photoluminescence quenching phenomenon occurs when the emitted light from one material is reabsorbed by another material, which can be used to control the light emission properties of nanocomposites.
Question_1006.Question: What happens to the photoluminescence intensity of upconversion nanoparticles when they are combined with gold nanoparticles that absorb the emitted light?
Question_1006.Source: We found that photoluminescence intensity gradually weakened as the posAuNP ratio increased, confirming that photon quenching occurred as a result of re-absorption of the upconverting photon emitted by UCNP by posAuNPs.

related_data.Title: Photoporation-Based Intracellular Delivery Using Upconversion Nanoparticles and Gold Nanoparticles
related_data.Abstract: Photoporation techniques based on plasmonic nanoparticles such as gold nanoparticles have been extensively studied for the intracellular delivery of substances via cell membrane disruption. This study employed upconversion nanoparticles to stimulate gold nanoparticles at near-infrared wavelengths, resulting in the production of posAuNP@UCNPs nanocomposites. The nanocomposites were effective for the delivery of baricitinib as a treatment for osteoarthritis in a three-dimensional osteoarthritis model. The findings suggest that posAuNP@UCNPs have great potential as a tool for non-invasive drug delivery via UCPPin.

Question_1008.Context: Resistive heating losses (RHL) occur when nanoparticles convert absorbed electromagnetic energy into heat, which can be used to induce local temperature increases and facilitate certain processes like photoporation.
Question_1008.Question: In the context of photoporation, what is the significance of an increase in resistive heating losses (RHL) when nanoparticles are irradiated with light?
Question_1008.A: It indicates a decrease in nanoparticle stability
Question_1008.B: It suggests an increase in the formation of vapor nanobubbles
Question_1008.C: It implies a reduction in the electric field strength
Question_1008.D: It means the nanoparticles are becoming less conductive
Question_1008.Source: The occurrence of exotherm is a critical factor for AuNP photoporation because it leads to the formation of vapor nanobubbles (VNBs), which burst and perforate the cell membrane.

related_data.Title: Composite Treatment Technology for Enhancing Biomass Preservation and Utilization
related_data.Abstract: Traditional autoclaving, slow degradation rate and preservation of biomass treated by fungi are the main factors restricting biological treatment. In our previous studies, strains with high efficiency and selective lignin degradation ability were obtained. To further solve the limiting factors of biological treatment, this paper proposed a composite treatment technology, which could replace autoclaves for fungal treatment and improve the preservation and utilization of fungal-pretreated straw. The autoclaved and expanded buckwheat straw were, respectively, degraded by Irpex lacteus for 14 days (CIL, EIL), followed by ensiling of raw materials (CK) and biodegraded straw of CIL and EIL samples with Lactobacillus plantarum for different days, respectively (CP, CIP, EIP). An expansion led to lactic acid bacteria, mold, and yeast of the samples below the detection line, and aerobic bacteria was significantly reduced, indicating a positive sterilization effect. Expansion before I. lacteus significantly enhanced lignin selective degradation by about 6%, and the absolute content of natural detergent solute was about 5% higher than that of the CIL. Moreover, EIL decreased pH by producing higher organic acids. The combination treatment created favorable conditions for ensiling. During ensiling, EIP silage produced high lactic acid about 26.83 g/kg DM and the highest acetic acid about 22.35 g/kg DM, and the pH value could be stable at 4.50. Expansion before I. lacteus optimized the microbial community for ensiling, resulting in EIP silage co-dominated by Lactobacillus, Pediococcus and Weissella, whereas only Lactobacillus was always dominant in CP and CIP silage. Clavispora gradually replaced Irpex in EIP silage, which potentially promoted lactic acid bacteria growth and acetic acid production. In vitro gas production (IVGP) in EIL was increased by 30% relative to CK and was higher than 24% in CIL. The role of expansion was more significant after ensiling, the IVGP in EIP was increased by 22% relative to CP, while that in CIP silage was only increased by 9%. Silage of fungal-treated samples reduced methane emissions by 28% to 31%. The study demonstrated that expansion provides advantages for fungal colonization and delignification, and further improves the microbial community and fermentation quality for silage, enhancing the nutrition and utilization value.
related_data.Institute of Origin: China Agricultural University
related_data.Funding: Modern Agro-industry Technology Research System of China (grant number CARS-07-E-3)

Question_1378.Context: In organic chemistry, acetic acid is a volatile fatty acid that can be produced during the fermentation process. It is known for its antimicrobial properties, which can be beneficial in the preservation of biomass.
Question_1378.Question: What is the significance of acetic acid production during biomass fermentation?
Question_1378.A: It enhances the sweetness of the biomass
Question_1378.B: It increases the protein content of the biomass
Question_1378.C: It has antimicrobial properties that aid in preservation
Question_1378.D: It promotes the growth of aerobic bacteria
Question_1378.Source: The AA accumulated the fastest in EIP silage throughout the ensiling compared to others, leading to the highest AA concentration about 22.35 g/kg DM on day 28.

related_data.Title: Composite Treatment Technology for Enhancing Biomass Preservation and Utilization
related_data.Abstract: Traditional autoclaving, slow degradation rate and preservation of biomass treated by fungi are the main factors restricting biological treatment. In our previous studies, strains with high efficiency and selective lignin degradation ability were obtained. To further solve the limiting factors of biological treatment, this paper proposed a composite treatment technology, which could replace autoclaves for fungal treatment and improve the preservation and utilization of fungal-pretreated straw. The autoclaved and expanded buckwheat straw were, respectively, degraded by Irpex lacteus for 14 days (CIL, EIL), followed by ensiling of raw materials (CK) and biodegraded straw of CIL and EIL samples with Lactobacillus plantarum for different days, respectively (CP, CIP, EIP). An expansion led to lactic acid bacteria, mold, and yeast of the samples below the detection line, and aerobic bacteria was significantly reduced, indicating a positive sterilization effect. Expansion before I. lacteus significantly enhanced lignin selective degradation by about 6%, and the absolute content of natural detergent solute was about 5% higher than that of the CIL. Moreover, EIL decreased pH by producing higher organic acids. The combination treatment created favorable conditions for ensiling. During ensiling, EIP silage produced high lactic acid about 26.83 g/kg DM and the highest acetic acid about 22.35 g/kg DM, and the pH value could be stable at 4.50. Expansion before I. lacteus optimized the microbial community for ensiling, resulting in EIP silage co-dominated by Lactobacillus, Pediococcus and Weissella, whereas only Lactobacillus was always dominant in CP and CIP silage. Clavispora gradually replaced Irpex in EIP silage, which potentially promoted lactic acid bacteria growth and acetic acid production. In vitro gas production (IVGP) in EIL was increased by 30% relative to CK and was higher than 24% in CIL. The role of expansion was more significant after ensiling, the IVGP in EIP was increased by 22% relative to CP, while that in CIP silage was only increased by 9%. Silage of fungal-treated samples reduced methane emissions by 28% to 31%. The study demonstrated that expansion provides advantages for fungal colonization and delignification, and further improves the microbial community and fermentation quality for silage, enhancing the nutrition and utilization value.

Question_1441.Context: Multidrug resistance-associated protein 1 (MRP1) is a transporter protein that pumps various compounds out of cells using the energy of ATP hydrolysis. It is involved in physiological and pathophysiological processes in the body.
Question_1441.Question: What is the primary function of Multidrug resistance-associated protein 1 (MRP1)?
Question_1441.B: Efflux of various compounds out of cells
Question_1441.Source: Multidrug resistance-associated protein 1 (MRP1) is a member of the adenosine triphosphate (ATP)-binding cassette superfamily of transporters and pumps various compounds, including therapeutic agents and physiological substances, out of cells using the energy of ATP hydrolysis.

related_data.Title: Improving the radiochemical yield of 6‑bromo‑7‑[11C]methylpurine for assessment of MRP1 activity in the human brain and lungs
related_data.Abstract: Multidrug resistance‑associated protein 1 (MRP1) plays a crucial role in various physiological and pathophysiological processes. The synthesis of 6‑bromo‑7‑[11C]methylpurine ([11C]7m6BP) for assessing MRP1 activity has been limited by low radiochemical yield due to the formation of the undesired isomer, 6‑bromo‑9‑[11C]methylpurine ([11C]9m6BP). This study investigated conditions to improve the [11C]7m6BP/[11C]9m6BP selectivity in the methylation reaction. The use of tetrahydrofuran (THF), 2‑methyltetrahydrofuran (2‑MeTHF), and ethyl acetate (AcOEt) significantly enhanced the selectivity, providing sufficient radioactivity for clinical use.
related_data.Institute of Origin: Department of Advanced Nuclear Medicine Sciences, Institute for Quantum Medical Science, National Institutes for Quantum Science and Technology, Japan
related_data.Funding: JSPS KAKENHI Grant Number JP22K07785, AMED Moonshot Research and Development Program Grant No. 21zf0127003h001
related_data.Methods: The study involved manual synthesis of [11C]7m6BP via methylation of 6‑bromopurine with [11C]CH3I in various solvents and temperatures. Automated synthesis was performed using [11C]methyl triflate. Radiochemical yields were determined by radio-HPLC and radio-TLC analyses.
related_data.Results: THF, 2‑MeTHF, and AcOEt improved the [11C]7m6BP/[11C]9m6BP selectivity in the methylation reaction. Starting from 28 to 34 GBq [11C]CO2, [11C]7m6BP was produced with 2.3–2.6 GBq for THF, 2.7–3.3 GBq for AcOEt, and 2.8–3.9 GBq for 2‑MeTHF at approximately 30 min after the end of bombardment.
related_data.Experiment details: The study investigated the impact of different solvents and temperatures on the radiochemical yield of [11C]7m6BP. The use of THF, 2‑MeTHF, and AcOEt showed promising results in improving the selectivity of [11C]7m6BP in the methylation reaction.

Question_1442.Context: In the synthesis of certain radiolabeled compounds, the use of different solvents can affect the selectivity and yield of the desired product.
Question_1442.Question: Which solvent improved the selectivity of [11C]7m6BP/[11C]9m6BP in the methylation reaction?
Question_1442.Source: Several less polar solvents, including tetrahydrofuran (THF), 2-methyltetrahydrofuran (2-MeTHF), and ethyl acetate (AcOEt) improved the [11C]7m6BP/[11C]9m6BP selectivity from 1:1 to 2:1, compared with the conventionally used solvents for the alkylation of 6-halopurines, acetone, acetonitrile, and N,N-dimethylformamide.

Question_1443.Context: The synthesis of radiolabeled compounds often requires the use of a methylating agent to introduce a radioactive carbon atom into the molecule.
Question_1443.Question: Which methylating agent was used to increase the conversion at a lower temperature in the synthesis of [11C]7m6BP?
Question_1443.Source: [11C]Methyl triflate ([11C]CH3OTf) was thus used as a methylating agent to increase the conversion at a lower temperature.

Question_1444.Context: In the context of organic synthesis, the reaction temperature can significantly influence the reaction rate and the solubility of reactants in the solvent.
Question_1444.Question: At what temperature did the 11C-methylation using [11C]CH3OTf proceed efficiently in solvents like THF, 2-MeTHF, and AcOEt?
Question_1444.Source: The 11C-methylation using [11C]CH3OTf at 100 °C proceeded efficiently in THF, 2-MeTHF, and AcOEt with maintenance of the improved selectivity.

Question_1445.Context: The radiochemical yield (RCY) is an important parameter in the synthesis of radiolabeled compounds, indicating the amount of desired radioactive product obtained from the starting material.
Question_1445.Question: What was the range of isolated RCYs (decay corrected) for the solvent 2-MeTHF in the synthesis of [11C]7m6BP?
Question_1445.Source: The isolated RCYs (decay corrected) for THF, 2-MeTHF, and AcOEt were 24-28%, 29-35%, and 22-31% (n = 3), respectively.

Question_1446.Question: Which solvent was observed to have poor solubility of 6-bromopurine, leading to a considerable amount of unreacted [11C]CH3I?
Question_1446.Source: When iPr2O, CHCl3, Tol, or DCM was used, a considerable amount of unreacted [11C]CH3I was observed, and the reaction scarcely proceeded even at high temperature (180 °C).

Question_1447.Context: The use of a less polar solvent in the alkylation reaction of 6-halopurines can influence the selectivity of the reaction towards the desired N7- or N9-alkylated purine isomer.
Question_1447.Question: Which of the following solvents did NOT improve the [11C]7m6BP/[11C]9m6BP selectivity to 2:1?
Question_1447.Source: While 1,4-DO and 2-MeTHF improved the [11C]7m6BP/[11C]9m6BP selectivity to 2:1, the methylation did not proceed efficiently. The use of less polar solvents—AcOMe, AcOEt, MP, THF, and 1,3-DO—appeared promising for increasing the RCY of [11C]7m6BP at 140 °C or 180 °C.

Question_1448.Context: In radiochemistry, the molar activity (Am) of a radiolabeled compound is a measure of the radioactivity per amount of substance and is an important parameter for determining the purity and usefulness of the compound.
Question_1448.Question: What was the range of molar activity (Am) for [11C]7m6BP when synthesized using THF as the solvent?
Question_1448.Source: The molar activity (Am) was determined by comparing the assayed radioactivity to the mass associated with the 7m6BP UV peak at 288 nm. The molar activity (Am) for THF was 140-180 GBq/µmol.

related_data.Title: Improving the radiochemical yield of 6‑bromo‑7‑[11C]methylpurine for assessment of MRP1 activity in the human brain and lungs
related_data.Abstract: Multidrug resistance‑associated protein 1 (MRP1) plays a crucial role in various physiological and pathophysiological processes. The synthesis of 6‑bromo‑7‑[11C]methylpurine ([11C]7m6BP) for assessing MRP1 activity has been limited by low radiochemical yield due to the formation of the undesired isomer, 6‑bromo‑9‑[11C]methylpurine ([11C]9m6BP). This study investigated conditions to improve the [11C]7m6BP/[11C]9m6BP selectivity in the methylation reaction. The use of tetrahydrofuran (THF), 2‑methyltetrahydrofuran (2‑MeTHF), and ethyl acetate (AcOEt) significantly enhanced the selectivity, providing sufficient radioactivity for clinical use.
related_data.Institute of Origin: Department of Advanced Nuclear Medicine Sciences, Institute for Quantum Medical Science, National Institutes for Quantum Science and Technology, Japan
related_data.Funding: JSPS KAKENHI Grant Number JP22K07785, AMED Moonshot Research and Development Program Grant No. 21zf0127003h001
related_data.Methods: The study involved manual synthesis of [11C]7m6BP via methylation of 6‑bromopurine with [11C]CH3I in various solvents and temperatures. Automated synthesis was performed using [11C]methyl triflate. Radiochemical yields were determined by radio-HPLC and radio-TLC analyses.
related_data.Results: THF, 2‑MeTHF, and AcOEt improved the [11C]7m6BP/[11C]9m6BP selectivity in the methylation reaction. Starting from 28 to 34 GBq [11C]CO2, [11C]7m6BP was produced with 2.3–2.6 GBq for THF, 2.7–3.3 GBq for AcOEt, and 2.8–3.9 GBq for 2‑MeTHF at approximately 30 min after the end of bombardment.
related_data.Experiment details: The study investigated the impact of different solvents and temperatures on the radiochemical yield of [11C]7m6BP. The use of THF, 2‑MeTHF, and AcOEt showed promising results in improving the selectivity of [11C]7m6BP in the methylation reaction.

Question_1449.Context: The synthesis of radiolabeled compounds for clinical use requires not only high selectivity and yield but also high radiochemical purity to ensure the safety and effectiveness of the compound.
Question_1449.Question: What was the radiochemical purity of [11C]7m6BP higher than 95% up to how many minutes after being formulated?
Question_1449.Source: The radiochemical purity of [11C]7m6BP was higher than 95% up to 60 min after being formulated.

Question_1450.Context: The synthesis of radiolabeled compounds often involves trapping a reactive intermediate, such as [11C]CH3OTf, in a mixture containing the precursor and a base.
Question_1450.Question: What base was used in the synthesis of [11C]7m6BP?
Question_1450.Source: Potassium Carbonate (K2CO3, guaranteed reagent) was purchased from FUJIFILM Wako Pure Chemical Corporation and was ground in a mortar into a fine powder, which was used for manual and automated syntheses.

Question_1481.Context: Sulfonamides are a class of antibiotics that can be added to animal feed to control and prevent diseases. They have a common structure which includes an unsubstituted amine on the benzene ring and a sulfonamide group.
Question_1481.Question: What is the common structure found in sulfonamides?
Question_1481.A: An unsubstituted amine on the benzene ring and a sulfonamide group
Question_1481.B: A hydroxyl group attached to a benzene ring
Question_1481.C: A carboxyl group parallel to an amine group
Question_1481.D: A nitro group attached to a cyclohexane ring
Question_1481.Source: Sulfonamides have a common structure of an unsubstituted amine on the benzene ring and a sulfonamide group parallel to the amine.

related_data.Title: Development of a Rapid Multi-Residue Analytical Method for Sulfonamides in Livestock Samples Using UHPLC-MS/MS
related_data.Abstract: The study presents the development of a rapid and efficient multi-residue analytical method for screening and confirming 31 sulfonamides in livestock samples using ultra-high-performance liquid chromatography combined with comprehensive mass spectrometric approaches. A novel sample preparation procedure based on a modified QuEChERS method was utilized. The method was validated according to Codex guidelines, demonstrating excellent linearity, sensitivity, accuracy, and precision. The applicability of the screening method was verified using real livestock samples, with none exceeding the maximum residue limit.
related_data.Institute of Origin: National Institute of Food and Drug Safety Evaluation, Ministry of Food and Drug Safety, Republic of Korea
related_data.Funding: This study was supported by the Ministry of Food and Drug Safety of the Republic of Korea (grant no. 22191MFDS317) in 2022.

Question_1482.Context: Sulfonamides act as competitive inhibitors of p-aminobenzoic acid during the folate metabolic cycle in bacteria, which is essential for nucleic acid synthesis.
Question_1482.Question: How do sulfonamides inhibit bacterial growth?
Question_1482.A: By disrupting the cell wall synthesis
Question_1482.C: By acting as competitive inhibitors of p-aminobenzoic acid during the folate metabolic cycle
Question_1482.Source: Sulfonamides are N-substituted derivatives of sulfanilamide that inhibit bacterial growth by acting as competitive inhibitors of p-aminobenzoic acid during the folate metabolic cycle.

Question_1485.Context: Analytical methods such as liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry (LC–MS) are used to detect and quantify sulfonamide residues in livestock products.
Question_1485.Question: Which analytical method is commonly used for the analysis of sulfonamide residues in livestock products?
Question_1485.Source: Numerous analytical methods have been developed for the screening and quantification of sulfonamides in livestock products. Such analytical methods are mainly based on microbiological assays, immunoassays, capillary electrophoresis, high performance liquid chromatography with diode array detection (HPLC–DAD), gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC–MS), liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry (LC–MS), and hydrophilic interaction chromatography-mass spectrometry.

Question_1489.Source: The limit of detection (LOD) and limit of quantification (LOQ) ranged from 0.3 to 5 ng g−1 and from 1 to 19 ng g−1 and the average recoveries (%) for three laboratories ranged from 85 to 109% with a CV (n = 5) below 22%.

Question_1521.Context: Endophytic microbiomes are microbial communities that reside within plant tissues for all or part of their lifetimes. These communities are nonpathogenic and can contribute to the host plant's health by enhancing fitness and providing protection against pathogen infection.
Question_1521.Question: What is the role of endophytic microbiomes in plants?
Question_1521.B: Enhancing plant fitness and providing protection against pathogens
Question_1521.D: Facilitating the spread of pathogens within the plant
Question_1521.Source: Microbes residing within plant tissues for all or part of their lifetime are considered as endophytes. Similar to the gut microbiota in humans, endophytes are nonpathogenic and presumably commensal with their hosts thus exhibiting contributions to host health, such as enhancing plant fitness and protecting the plant from pathogen infection.

related_data.Title: Endophytic Microbiome Response and Plant Defense System Enhancement Against Bacterial Wilt Disease
related_data.Abstract: The study investigates the response of endophytic root and stem microbiomes and the defense system of tobacco plants to Ralstonia solanacearum, a bacterial pathogen causing bacterial wilt disease. The results show a reduction in community diversity and changes in microbial composition in tobacco root and stem compartments upon R. solanacearum infection. Beneficial endophytic microbes enriched in diseased root and stem compartments exhibit antagonistic activities against R. solanacearum. The expression of key genes participating in plant defense signaling pathways and activities of plant defense enzymes are activated with R. solanacearum infection. Inoculation of beneficial endophyte Burkholderia ASV_550 in soils greatly enhances the tobacco defense system in the presence of the pathogen and decreases disease incidence.
related_data.Journal: Chemical and Biological Technologies in Agriculture
related_data.Institute of Origin: Beijing Life Science Academy, China Tobacco Gene Research Center, Zhengzhou Tobacco Research Institute of CNTC, Molecular Genetics Key Laboratory of China Tobacco, Guizhou Academy of Tobacco, School of Agricultural Sciences, Zhengzhou University
related_data.Funding: Innovation Projects of Zhengzhou Tobacco Research Institute, Scientific and Technological Project of Henan Province
related_data.Methods: The study involved microbial community analysis, culture-based methods, and quantification of plant defense genes. Sample collection, DNA extraction, amplicon sequencing, data processing, bacterial isolation, in vitro antagonistic activities testing, quantification of defense-related genes, and measurement of defense-related enzyme activities were performed.
related_data.Results: The study found a significant reduction in community diversity and changes in microbial composition in tobacco root and stem compartments upon R. solanacearum infection. Beneficial endophytic microbes enriched in diseased compartments exhibited antagonistic activities against R. solanacearum. The expression of key genes involved in plant defense signaling pathways and activities of defense enzymes were activated with R. solanacearum infection. Inoculation of beneficial endophyte Burkholderia ASV_550 enhanced the tobacco defense system and reduced disease incidence.
related_data.Experiment details: The study aimed to elucidate the changes in bacterial and fungal communities in tobacco root and stem endophytic compartments under bacterial wilt disease. The recruitment of beneficial microbes upon pathogen invasion was investigated, and the potential mechanisms underlying the mutualistic interactions between beneficial endophytes and plants in resisting pathogen infection were explored.

Question_1522.Context: Beneficial microbes can suppress plant diseases through direct interactions with pathogens, which includes the secretion of secondary metabolites with antimicrobial properties.
Question_1522.Question: How can beneficial microbes directly suppress plant pathogens?
Question_1522.A: By increasing the nutrient absorption of the plant
Question_1522.C: By secreting secondary metabolites with antimicrobial properties
Question_1522.D: By inducing physical barriers in plant tissues
Question_1522.Source: On the one hand, beneficial microbes can kill the pathogens directly by secreting diverse secondary metabolites. The common example of bacterial endophytes resist to pathogen is the genus Bacillus, which directly inhibited the proliferation of plant pathogens by producing lipopeptides and polyketides with antimicrobial properties.

Question_1523.A: Gibberellic acid and abscisic acid pathways
Question_1523.D: Salicylic acid and gibberellic acid pathways
Question_1523.Source: The plant ISR is mainly controlled by jasmonic acid (JA) and ethylene (ET) signaling pathways.

Question_1661.Question: What is the typical length range of microRNAs (miRNAs)?

related_data.Title: Development of a Proximity-CHA-DNAzyme System for Highly Sensitive miRNA Detection
related_data.Abstract: Aberrant expression of microRNAs (miRNAs) has been shown to be linked to several crucial biological processes, including as carcinogenesis, metastasis, and progression. The advancement of innovative miRNA detection technologies can enhance the early detection of malignancies by merging with conventional diagnostic methods, such as ultrasound technology. Herein, we reported a simple, sensitive, and label-free miRNA detection method by integrating the proximity-catalytic hairpin assembly (proximity-CHA) and DNAzyme-assisted signal amplification. Compared with traditional CHA, in which the signal amplification efficiency is greatly limited by the concentration of hairpin probes, the proposed method possesses a greatly improved signal amplification efficiency. The target facilitated the non-enzymatic CHA-driven sequential formation of DNAzyme nanostructures, resulting in the effective DNAzyme-facilitated cleavage of a substrate modified with a fluorophore and quencher, leading to the production of an intensified fluorescence signal. The proximity-CHA-DNAzyme system possesses appealing analytical characteristics, making it highly promising for the analysis of many analytes in clinical research domains.
related_data.Institute of Origin: Medical Ultrasound Center, Northwest Women’s and Children’s Hospital, Xi’an 710061, Shaanxi, China
related_data.Funding: No fund available
related_data.Methods: The study integrated proximity-CHA with DNAzyme-assisted signal amplification for highly sensitive miRNA detection. Various experimental parameters were optimized, including concentrations of probes, incubation time, temperature, and Mg2+ concentration. The dynamic range, sensitivity, and selectivity for miRNA detection were evaluated under ideal conditions.
related_data.Results: The developed biosensor exhibited a low detection limit of 3.2 fM and demonstrated high selectivity in detecting miRNA targets. Real sample analysis using RNA lysate solutions from human cancer cell lines showed promising results in detecting miRNA-21. The biosensor showed high selectivity in clinical samples and the ability to identify infrequent miRNA targets.
related_data.Experiment details: The experiment involved the design and optimization of a proximity-CHA-DNAzyme system for miRNA detection. The study focused on enhancing signal amplification efficiency and sensitivity for early detection of malignancies. Various experimental parameters were optimized to achieve the best performance of the biosensor.

Question_1666.Context: Catalytic hairpin assembly (CHA) is an isothermal reaction used for nucleic acid detection, which operates based on the cross-opening of two DNA hairpins.
Question_1666.Question: What does the catalytic hairpin assembly (CHA) process result in the production of?
Question_1666.Source: In this reaction, an initiator facilitates the cross-opening of two DNA hairpins, resulting in the production of multiple double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) molecules.

related_data.Title: Development of a Proximity-CHA-DNAzyme System for Highly Sensitive miRNA Detection
related_data.Abstract: Aberrant expression of microRNAs (miRNAs) has been shown to be linked to several crucial biological processes, including as carcinogenesis, metastasis, and progression. The advancement of innovative miRNA detection technologies can enhance the early detection of malignancies by merging with conventional diagnostic methods, such as ultrasound technology. Herein, we reported a simple, sensitive, and label-free miRNA detection method by integrating the proximity-catalytic hairpin assembly (proximity-CHA) and DNAzyme-assisted signal amplification. Compared with traditional CHA, in which the signal amplification efficiency is greatly limited by the concentration of hairpin probes, the proposed method possesses a greatly improved signal amplification efficiency. The target facilitated the non-enzymatic CHA-driven sequential formation of DNAzyme nanostructures, resulting in the effective DNAzyme-facilitated cleavage of a substrate modified with a fluorophore and quencher, leading to the production of an intensified fluorescence signal. The proximity-CHA-DNAzyme system possesses appealing analytical characteristics, making it highly promising for the analysis of many analytes in clinical research domains.
related_data.Institute of Origin: Medical Ultrasound Center, Northwest Women’s and Children’s Hospital, Xi’an 710061, Shaanxi, China
related_data.Funding: No fund available
related_data.Methods: The study integrated proximity-CHA with DNAzyme-assisted signal amplification for highly sensitive miRNA detection. Various experimental parameters were optimized, including concentrations of probes, incubation time, temperature, and Mg2+ concentration. The dynamic range, sensitivity, and selectivity for miRNA detection were evaluated under ideal conditions.
related_data.Results: The developed biosensor exhibited a low detection limit of 3.2 fM and demonstrated high selectivity in detecting miRNA targets. Real sample analysis using RNA lysate solutions from human cancer cell lines showed promising results in detecting miRNA-21. The biosensor showed high selectivity in clinical samples and the ability to identify infrequent miRNA targets.
related_data.Experiment details: The experiment involved the design and optimization of a proximity-CHA-DNAzyme system for miRNA detection. The study focused on enhancing signal amplification efficiency and sensitivity for early detection of malignancies. Various experimental parameters were optimized to achieve the best performance of the biosensor.

Question_1667.Context: DNAzymes are catalytic DNA molecules that have been used as amplifying labels in biosensing due to their inherent advantages.
Question_1667.Question: Which of the following is NOT an inherent advantage of DNAzymes compared to protein enzymes?
Question_1667.Source: Compared to protein enzymes, DNAzymes possess inherent advantages in terms of their design flexibility and cost-effectiveness.

Question_1670.Context: The development of new miRNA detection methods can aid in the early detection of malignancies by complementing traditional diagnostic methods.
Question_1670.Question: What is the detection limit of the newly developed miRNA-21 assay using the proximity-CHA-activated DNAzyme system?
Question_1670.Source: As a simple sensing strategy, the proximity-CHA-activated DNAzyme system enabled the sensitive miRNA-21 assay with a low detection limit. The low detection limit was determined to be 3.2 fM.

Question_1871.Context: Biostimulants are used to enhance plant growth and resilience to environmental stress. They can modulate plant physiological processes, but their exact mechanisms of action are often not well understood.
Question_1871.Question: What is the primary target of heat damage in the photosynthetic machinery of plants?
Question_1871.Source: The photosynthetic apparatus in the chloroplast is the primary target of heat damage by the overproduction of reactive oxygen species (ROS) causing oxidative damage to biomolecules including pigments, proteins, lipids and DNA leading to cellular injuries and cell death. PSII is the most sensitive component of the photosynthetic machinery to excessive ROS damage, thus plants activate photoprotective mechanisms with one of them being upregulation of non-photochemical quenching (NPQ) causing depression of PSII activity to avoid damage to PSII reaction centres.

related_data.Title: Mechanism of Plant Thermotolerance Exerted by the Biostimulant Quantis™ Under Heat Stress
related_data.Abstract: Raising global temperatures limit crop productivity and new strategies are needed to improve the resilience of thermosensitive crops such as potato (Solanum tuberosum L.). Biostimulants are emerging as potential crop protection products against environmental stress, however their mechanism of action remains largely unknown, hindering their wider adoption. We used comprehensive physiological, molecular, and mass spectrometry approaches to develop understanding of the mechanism of plant thermotolerance exerted by the biostimulant, Quantis™, under heat stress.
related_data.Journal: Chemical Biology and Technology in Agriculture
related_data.Institute of Origin: University of Nottingham, School of Biosciences
related_data.Funding: Syngenta, UK (project 4815305)
related_data.Methods: Physiological, molecular, and mass spectrometry approaches were used to study the mechanism of plant thermotolerance exerted by the biostimulant Quantis™ under heat stress. Detailed experimental setups and techniques were employed to analyze the effects of the biostimulant on plant responses to heat stress.
related_data.Results: Quantis™ application prior to heat stress effectively primed heat tolerance responses and alleviated temperature stress of Solanum tuberosum L. and A. thaliana by modulating the expression and function of PR4 and MEE59 and by regulating CK activity above and below ground. The biostimulant resulted in increased tuber weight and size, mitigating negative effects of heat stress on tuber growth.
related_data.Experiment details: The experiment involved the growth of potato plants under heat stress conditions following application of the biostimulant Quantis™. Various physiological, molecular, and genetic analyses were conducted to understand the mechanisms underlying plant thermotolerance in response to the biostimulant.

Question_1872.Context: Certain enzymes are involved in the biosynthesis of flavonoids, a group of compounds with potent antioxidant functions that can enhance plant tolerance to various environmental stresses.
Question_1872.Question: Which enzyme catalyses the hydroxylation at the 3′-position of dihydrokaempferol to yield dihydroquercetin in the flavonoid biosynthesis pathway?
Question_1872.Source: Flavonoid 3′‐hydroxylase (F3′H) catalyses hydroxylation at the 3′‐position of dihydrokaempferol to yield dihydroquercetin downstream of naringenin, directing flavonoid biosynthesis towards some of the most potent biological compounds with antioxidant function including anthocyanins.

Question_1873.Context: Plants have developed various mechanisms to dissipate excess energy under stress conditions to protect the photosynthetic apparatus.
Question_1873.Question: What is the term used to describe the process by which plants dissipate excess excitation energy in the light-harvesting complexes of PSII to avoid damage?
Question_1873.Source: Under high leaf temperature or light, plants deploy photoprotective mechanisms to avoid irreversible damage to photosystem II (PSII) in the chloroplast caused by excessive energy generated by light-harvesting complexes. The primary, rapidly activated mechanism to thermally dissipate un-used energy for photochemistry is non-photochemical quenching (NPQ).

Question_1874.Context: Phytohormones play a significant role in regulating plant responses to environmental stress, including heat stress.
Question_1874.Question: Which phytohormone is known to be a major environmental stress response regulator and is also involved in the regulation of tuber induction, development, and tuberisation in potato?
Question_1874.Source: The phytohormones, abscisic acid (ABA), gibberellins (GAs), auxin (indole acetic acid, IAA), cytokinins (CKs), salicylic acid (SA) and jasmonic acid (JA) are the major environmental stress response regulators, whilst in potato CKs, GAs, and IAA also control tuber induction, development, and tuberisation.

Question_1875.Context: During environmental stress, such as heat stress, plants can activate secondary metabolic pathways under genetic control modulated by phytohormone signalling.
Question_1875.Question: Which class of proteins, known to be involved in plant defence, includes enzymes that degrade chitin of fungal or insect origin?
Question_1875.Source: Simultaneously, defence and secondary metabolic pathways are activated under genetic control modulated by phytohormone signalling and crosstalk to balance plant growth against environmental stress response.

Question_1876.Context: In the context of plant stress responses, certain proteins are known to be induced by both biotic and abiotic stress factors.
Question_1876.Question: What is the function of the plant protein family that includes chitinases of Class II?
Question_1876.A: To catalyse the hydrolysis of pectin
Question_1876.B: To degrade chitin and provide defence against pathogens
Question_1876.C: To protect plants from ultraviolet radiation
Question_1876.D: To regulate the opening and closing of stomata
Question_1876.Source: DEGs upregulated in Quantis™-treated plants in comparison to the control enriched significantly GO terms including ribosome and structural constituent of ribosome (n = 39), structural molecule activity (n = 41), defence response (n = 29), chitinase activity (n = 5), isoprenoid binding (n = 4), glucosidase activity (n = 4), abscisic acid binding (n = 4), enzyme inhibitor activity (n = 17), oxidoreductase activity acting on paired donors, with oxidation of a pair of donors resulting in the reduction of molecular oxygen to two molecules of water (n = 6), alcohol binding (n = 4) and carbon–carbon lyase activity (n = 12).

Question_1878.Question: What type of protein is the pathogenesis protein 4 (PR4) orthologue in Arabidopsis, which is involved in the plant defence response?
Question_1878.Source: Hevein-like preproprotein WIN1 and pathogen- and wound-inducible antifungal protein CBP20 were identified as the pathogenesis protein 4 (PR4) orthologue in Arabidopsis, encoding a chitinase of Class II.

related_data.Journal: Chemical Biology and Technology in Agriculture
related_data.Institute of Origin: University of Nottingham, School of Biosciences

related_data.Methods: Physiological, molecular, and mass spectrometry approaches were used to study the mechanism of plant thermotolerance exerted by the biostimulant Quantis™ under heat stress. Question_1901.Context: In the interactions between plants, insect herbivores, and pathogens, the host plants can influence the infectivity of pathogens targeting the herbivorous insects.

Question_1901.B: Host plants can modify the infectivity of pathogens that target herbivorous insects.
Question_1901.C: Host plants have no significant role and do not interact with either herbivores or pathogens.
Question_1901.D: Host plants solely act as a food source for herbivores and have no impact on pathogen infectivity.
Question_1901.Source: Plants play an important role in interactions between insect herbivores and their pathogens. The ability of host plants to modify the infectivity of entomopathogens in herbivorous insects has been widely documented.

related_data.Title: Plant-Mediated Effects of Hyphantria cunea Nucleopolyhedrovirus on the Fall Webworm: The Role of Nutrient Components in Host Plants
related_data.Abstract: Plants play an important role in interactions between insect herbivores and their pathogens. The ability of host plants to modify the infectivity of entomopathogens in herbivorous insects has been widely documented. However, the plants’ nutrients have always been neglected as a factor contributing to variation in the susceptibility of insect herbivores to entomopathogens. The fall-webworm (FWW), Hyphantria cunea Drury, is a typical polyphagous caterpillar, and the Hyphantria cunea nucleopolyhedrovirus (HycuNPV) is a distinctly specialized baculovirus for the FWW, which is safe for other organisms and has been effectively used as a biological insecticide against H. cunea in China. In this study, we investigated the nutrient components of four host plant species, i.e., Prunus serrulate, Cerasus serrulate, Camptotheca acuminata, and Populus deltoides, and their effects on the susceptibility of H. cunea larvae to HycuNPV. The HycuNPV-infected larvae fed on P. deltoides leaves exhibited higher survival rates, longer survival times, more food intake, and gained larger body size. These biological parameters were positively correlated with the nitrogen components of host plant leaves. Moreover, the larval antioxidant enzymes exhibited different responses to HycuNPV. HycuNPV infection significantly triggered the catalase (CAT) and prophenoloxidase (PPO) enzyme activity levels of H. cunea larvae. The uninfected larvae fed on poplar leaves induced a robust increase in the POD activity, which could scavenge extra reactive oxygen species and provide a protective effect against the HycuNPV. In conclusion, the plant-mediated effects of HycuNPV on the FWW have been investigated in this study. The nitrogen content in dietary was an essential factor in determining the insect herbivore susceptibility to entomopathogenic viruses, and it helped explain variations in the susceptibility of pests to the entomopathogenic viruses and aid in developing more robust tolerance monitoring assays in the lab that reflect the performance of pests in the field.
related_data.Institute of Origin: Nanjing Forestry University
related_data.Funding: National Key R&D Program of China (2022YFC2601002 and 2021YFD1400300)
related_data.Methods: The study investigated the nutrient components of four host plant species and their effects on the susceptibility of H. cunea larvae to HycuNPV. The HycuNPV-infected larvae were fed on different host plant leaves and various biological parameters were measured. Enzyme analysis was conducted to assess the antioxidant enzyme responses of the larvae. Statistical analysis was performed to analyze the effects of HycuNPV infection and different host plants on feeding behavior and enzyme activities.
related_data.Results: The results showed that the survival rate and time of HycuNPV-infected caterpillars were significantly affected by feeding on different host plants. The larvae fed on poplar leaves exhibited higher survival rates and longer survival times. The antioxidant enzyme responses of the larvae were also influenced by the host plant species. Additionally, the nitrogen content in host plant leaves was positively correlated with the survival rate, LT50, and dry weight gain of HycuNPV-infected larvae.
related_data.Experiment details: The experiment involved collecting H. cunea eggs from mulberry leaves, rearing the larvae on artificial diets, establishing strains of H. cunea on different host plants, infecting the larvae with HycuNPV, and measuring various biological parameters including survival rates, enzyme activities, and nutrient components of host plants. Statistical analyses were conducted to assess the impact of host plants and HycuNPV infection on the feeding behavior and enzyme activities of the larvae.

related_data.Title: Plant-Mediated Effects of Hyphantria cunea Nucleopolyhedrovirus on the Fall Webworm: The Role of Nutrient Components in Host Plants
related_data.Abstract: Plants play an important role in interactions between insect herbivores and their pathogens. The ability of host plants to modify the infectivity of entomopathogens in herbivorous insects has been widely documented. However, the plants’ nutrients have always been neglected as a factor contributing to variation in the susceptibility of insect herbivores to entomopathogens. The fall-webworm (FWW), Hyphantria cunea Drury, is a typical polyphagous caterpillar, and the Hyphantria cunea nucleopolyhedrovirus (HycuNPV) is a distinctly specialized baculovirus for the FWW, which is safe for other organisms and has been effectively used as a biological insecticide against H. cunea in China. The uninfected larvae fed on poplar leaves induced a robust increase in the POD activity, which could scavenge extra reactive oxygen species and provide a protective effect against the HycuNPV. Question_1961.Context: Beta-cyclodextrins (β-CDs) are cyclic oligosaccharides that can form inclusion complexes with various hydrophobic molecules, potentially altering the physicochemical properties of the guest compounds.
Question_1961.Question: What is the primary structural feature of beta-cyclodextrins (β-CDs) that allows them to interact with hydrophobic molecules?
Question_1961.Source: The hydrophobic inner cavity of CDs can harbor nonpolar and size-fit polyphenols such as Res. Furthermore, the delivery capability of CDs originates from their chemical properties.

related_data.Title: Plasma-polymerized OMBTSTS surface for efficient formation of tumor spheroids and enhanced anticancer activity of Resveratrol/Cyclodextrin
related_data.Abstract: Beta-cyclodextrins (β-CDs) comprise a pore for accommodating resveratrol (Res), thereby boosting its bioavailability. Res-incorporated β-CD (Res/CD) may be cytotoxic against both normal and cancer cells. Herein, we examined whether Res/CD exhibits anticancer activity against tumor spheroids, similar to in vivo tumor mass. To prepare three-dimensional spheroids, 1,1,1,3,5,7,7,7 octamethyl-3,5-bis(trimethylsiloxyl) tetrasiloxane (OMBTSTS) was deposited to the surface of the culture dish via plasma polymerization. We observed that HeLa cells grew as spheroids on the OMBTSTS-deposited surface at 20 W plasma power. Res/CD was delivered to the hypoxic core of the spheroid, inducing necrosis, whereas Res was not. Consistently, 10 μM Res alone was not cytotoxic to two-dimensional HeLa cells grown on a culture dish and three-dimensional spheroids. However, Res/CD promoted the necroptosis of spheroids, which were split into small fragments, ultimately inducing cell spheroid death. Collectively, our data suggest that nontoxic levels of Res/CD were efficiently delivered to the hypoxic core of tumor spheroids, promoting cell death. Therefore, Res/CD can be used as an effective anticancer drug. Moreover, the plasma-polymerized OMBTSTS modification technique provides insights into the efficient formation of spheroids in various cancer cell lines.
related_data.Journal: Journal of Analytical Science and Technology
related_data.Institute of Origin: Dankook University, South Korea
related_data.Funding: Basic Science Research Program of the National Research Foundation of Korea and Ministry of Education, Science, and Technology
related_data.Methods: Surface modification using plasma-enhanced chemical vapor deposition (PECVD) with OMBTSTS precursor, generation of HeLa cell spheroids, viability tests, western blotting, flow cytometry, fluorescence imaging
related_data.Results: Efficient delivery of Res/CD to hypoxic core of tumor spheroids, promotion of cell death, enhanced anticancer activity compared to Res alone
related_data.Experiment details: Detailed experimentation on the formation of tumor spheroids using plasma-polymerized OMBTSTS surface, evaluation of anticancer activity of Res/CD on spheroids, comparison with Res alone, assessment of necrosis and apoptosis induction

Question_1965.Context: Tumor spheroids are three-dimensional cell models that mimic the architecture and microenvironment of tumors, providing a platform for evaluating drug delivery and efficacy.

Question_1965.C: They mirror real tumors in terms of tissue architecture

Question_1965.Source: Nevertheless, 3D spheroids, similar to tumors, are more beneficial for developing new antitumor drugs because 2D-grown cells do not mirror real tumors in terms of tissue architecture and physiological microenvironments, including nutrient and oxygen transport.

Herein, we examined whether Res/CD exhibits anticancer activity against tumor spheroids, similar to in vivo tumor mass. To prepare three-dimensional spheroids, 1,1,1,3,5,7,7,7 octamethyl-3,5-bis(trimethylsiloxyl) tetrasiloxane (OMBTSTS) was deposited to the surface of the culture dish via plasma polymerization. We observed that HeLa cells grew as spheroids on the OMBTSTS-deposited surface at 20 W plasma power. Res/CD was delivered to the hypoxic core of the spheroid, inducing necrosis, whereas Res was not. Consistently, 10 μM Res alone was not cytotoxic to two-dimensional HeLa cells grown on a culture dish and three-dimensional spheroids. However, Res/CD promoted the necroptosis of spheroids, which were split into small fragments, ultimately inducing cell spheroid death. Collectively, our data suggest that nontoxic levels of Res/CD were efficiently delivered to the hypoxic core of tumor spheroids, promoting cell death. Therefore, Res/CD can be used as an effective anticancer drug. Moreover, the plasma-polymerized OMBTSTS modification technique provides insights into the efficient formation of spheroids in various cancer cell lines.

related_data.Title: Controlled Biodegradation of Cellulose Nanofibers by Incorporating Lignin
related_data.Abstract: Pure cellulose nanofibers (CNFs) rapidly degrade in soil, limiting their prospective applications in agriculture. We incorporated lignin into CNFs as an antimicrobial and crosslinking agent to control the biodegradation rate. CNFs with different lignin concentrations were prepared by mechanochemical treatment in the presence of choline chloride-urea deep eutectic solvent. These were characterized using conductometric titration, scanning electron microscopy, and FT-IR. The fibers were applied to soil to determine the effect of lignin on soil respiration and nanocellulose degradation, and were used as a substrate for radish and cress seed germination. Modifying the lignin content of the fibers successfully modulated the biodegradation rate in soil. Fibers containing 35% lignin degraded 5.7% in 14 days, while fibers with 20% lignin degraded 20.8% in 14 days. Nanofiber suspensions showed low chemical inhibition for the germination of radish and cress seeds but higher lignin contents reduced the imbibition rate as a seed coating. This study presents the first use of lignin to control the biodegradation rate of cellulose nanofibers in a one-pot, scalable and sustainable system, allowing the advancement of lignocellulose nanofibers for applications such as seed coatings, mulches, and controlled release fertilizers.
related_data.Journal: Chemical and Biological Technologies in Agriculture
related_data.Institute of Origin: Bioresource Processing Research Institute of Australia, Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Clayton, VIC, Australia
related_data.Funding: Australian Research Council (ARC), Norske Skog, Australian Paper, Visy, Orora, Government of Tasmania through the Industry Transformation Research Hub Processing Advanced Lignocellulosics (PALS) grant IH130100016, Australian Research Council Industrial Transformation Training Centre Award (Green Chemistry in Manufacturing, project number IC190100034)
related_data.Methods: Alkaline-peroxide bleaching of wood fibers, synthesis of lignocellulose nanofibers via mechanochemical treatment, characterization using FT-IR, conductometric titration, SEM imaging, UV absorption analysis, soil incubation experiment, sugars analysis, gas emissions analysis, seed germination experiments
related_data.Results: Adjusting lignin content modulated the biodegradation rate of cellulose nanofibers, higher lignin content resulted in slower degradation rate. Lignin incorporation showed no chemical inhibitory effects on seed germination but physical effects were observed when used as a seed coating.
related_data.Experiment details: The study aimed to develop sustainable nanocellulose materials for agricultural applications by incorporating lignin to control biodegradation rate. The process involved succinylation of lignocellulose nanofibers with varying lignin concentrations, characterization, soil incubation experiments, and seed germination assays.

Question_2068.Source: Nanofibers were produced via mechanochemical ball milling each bleached pulp and the unbleached TMP in a deep eutectic solvent consisting of urea and choline chloride in a molar ratio of 2 mol urea to 1 mol choline chloride.

related_data.Title: Controlled Biodegradation of Cellulose Nanofibers by Incorporating Lignin
related_data.Abstract: Pure cellulose nanofibers (CNFs) rapidly degrade in soil, limiting their prospective applications in agriculture. We incorporated lignin into CNFs as an antimicrobial and crosslinking agent to control the biodegradation rate. CNFs with different lignin concentrations were prepared by mechanochemical treatment in the presence of choline chloride-urea deep eutectic solvent. These were characterized using conductometric titration, scanning electron microscopy, and FT-IR. The fibers were applied to soil to determine the effect of lignin on soil respiration and nanocellulose degradation, and were used as a substrate for radish and cress seed germination. Modifying the lignin content of the fibers successfully modulated the biodegradation rate in soil. Fibers containing 35% lignin degraded 5.7% in 14 days, while fibers with 20% lignin degraded 20.8% in 14 days. Nanofiber suspensions showed low chemical inhibition for the germination of radish and cress seeds but higher lignin contents reduced the imbibition rate as a seed coating. This study presents the first use of lignin to control the biodegradation rate of cellulose nanofibers in a one-pot, scalable and sustainable system, allowing the advancement of lignocellulose nanofibers for applications such as seed coatings, mulches, and controlled release fertilizers.
