Question_2411.Context: Nano-enabled fertilizers can be synthesized using various procedures, one of which involves the impregnation of nanostructured materials with nutrient compounds.
Question_2411.Question: What compounds were used to impregnate nanostructured date palm pits to synthesize nano-enabled fertilizers?
Question_2411.Source: The NEF (nDPF1and nDPF2) were prepared by impregnation of nanostructured date palm pits (nDPP) with (KH2PO4 + MgO) at 1:1 and 3:1 (w/w) ratios respectively.

related_data.Title: Development of nano-enabled fertilizers from green waste using planetary ball milling procedure
related_data.Abstract: Development of nano-enabled fertilizers from green waste is one of the effective options to enhance global agricultural productions and minimize environmental pollution. Novel, eco-friendly and cost-effective nano-enabled fertilizers (NEF) were synthesized using the planetary ball milling procedure. The NEF (nDPF1 and nDPF2) were prepared by impregnation of nanostructured date palm pits (nDPP) with (KH2PO4 + MgO) at 1:1 and 3:1 (w/w) ratios respectively. The nDPP, nDPF1 and nDPF2 were extensively characterized. The produced nano-fertilizers enhanced soil water retention capacity with nDPF2 being the most effective. The water retention capacity of nDPF2 treated soil was 5.6 times higher than that of soil treated with conventional fertilizers. In addition, the nDPF2 exhibited superior sustained lower release rates of P, K and Mg nutrients for longer release periods in comparison with the conventional fertilizers. Findings from FTIR and XPS analyses suggested that hydrogen bonding and ligand exchange were the main interaction mechanisms of PO4-K-Mg ions with nDPP surface. The released kinetics data of the NEF revealed that power function was the best suitable model to describe the kinetics of P, K and Mg release data from NEF in water and soil. Pot study ascertained that the nano-enabled fertilizers (nDPF1 and nDPF2) significantly promoted biomass production and nutrient uptake of maize plants as compared to commercial fertilizer treated plants. The present work demonstrated the potential of NEF to increase nutrients uptake efficiency, mitigate moisture retention problem in arid soils and reduce nutrients loss through leaching and safeguard the environment.
related_data.Institute of Origin: Arid Lands Cultivation Research Institute, City of Scientific Research and Technological Applications, New Borg El-Arab, Alexandria, Egypt
related_data.Funding: Science, Technology & Innovation Funding Authority (STDF) in cooperation with Egyptian Knowledge Bank (EKB)
related_data.Methods: The nano-enabled fertilizers (NEF) were synthesized using the planetary ball milling procedure. The NEF (nDPF1 and nDPF2) were prepared by impregnation of nanostructured date palm pits (nDPP) with (KH2PO4 + MgO) at specific ratios. Extensive characterization of nDPP, nDPF1 and nDPF2 was conducted. FTIR and XPS analyses were performed to study the interaction mechanisms of PO4-K-Mg ions with nDPP surface. Kinetics of P, K and Mg release from NEF in water and soil were studied using various models.
related_data.Results: The nano-enabled fertilizers (NEF) showed enhanced soil water retention capacity and sustained lower release rates of P, K and Mg nutrients compared to conventional fertilizers. The power function model was found to be the most suitable for describing the kinetics of nutrient release from NEF. Pot study demonstrated that NEF significantly promoted biomass production and nutrient uptake of maize plants compared to commercial fertilizer treated plants.
related_data.Experiment details: The study focused on the development of nano-enabled fertilizers from green waste using a planetary ball milling procedure. The experiment involved synthesizing NEF (nDPF1 and nDPF2) by impregnating nanostructured date palm pits (nDPP) with (KH2PO4 + MgO) at specific ratios. Extensive characterization of nDPP, nDPF1 and nDPF2 was conducted using various analytical techniques. The study also investigated the water retention behavior, nutrient release kinetics, and plant growth promotion effects of NEF compared to conventional fertilizers.

Question_2414.Context: The use of agroindustry byproducts in the synthesis of nano-enabled fertilizers can contribute to environmental sustainability by repurposing waste materials.
Question_2414.Question: What byproduct is used as a carrier in the synthesis of nano-enabled fertilizers to control the release of macronutrients?
Question_2414.Source: The main goal of this study was to produce nano-enabled fertilizers- based green waste and to evaluate its nutrients release pattern and kinetics. This study is the first to investigate the potential of nanostructured date-pits as a carrier to control the macronutrients release and to provide low-cost and agro-ecological solution through the sustainable reuse of natural sources.

Question_2416.D: Amorphous nature with no distinct peaks
Question_2416.Source: The XRD results of natural byproducts of date industry (date pits) in nanoscale (nDPP) are presented in Fig. 2B. No diffraction peaks analogous to crystallinity were observed, which evidently demonstrated the amorphous nature of DPP nanoparticles carrier.

Question_2417.Context: The water retention capacity of soil can be enhanced by the addition of certain materials, which can be crucial for maintaining moisture in arid conditions.
Question_2417.Question: Which nano-enabled fertilizer showed the most effective enhancement in soil water retention capacity?
Question_2417.Source: The produced nano-fertilizers enhanced soil water retention capacity with nDPF2 being the most effective. The water retention capacity of nDPF2 treated soil was 5.6 times higher than that of soil treated with conventional fertilizers.

related_data.Title: Development of nano-enabled fertilizers from green waste using planetary ball milling procedure
related_data.Abstract: Development of nano-enabled fertilizers from green waste is one of the effective options to enhance global agricultural productions and minimize environmental pollution. Novel, eco-friendly and cost-effective nano-enabled fertilizers (NEF) were synthesized using the planetary ball milling procedure. The NEF (nDPF1 and nDPF2) were prepared by impregnation of nanostructured date palm pits (nDPP) with (KH2PO4 + MgO) at 1:1 and 3:1 (w/w) ratios respectively. The nDPP, nDPF1 and nDPF2 were extensively characterized. The produced nano-fertilizers enhanced soil water retention capacity with nDPF2 being the most effective. The water retention capacity of nDPF2 treated soil was 5.6 times higher than that of soil treated with conventional fertilizers. In addition, the nDPF2 exhibited superior sustained lower release rates of P, K and Mg nutrients for longer release periods in comparison with the conventional fertilizers. Findings from FTIR and XPS analyses suggested that hydrogen bonding and ligand exchange were the main interaction mechanisms of PO4-K-Mg ions with nDPP surface. The released kinetics data of the NEF revealed that power function was the best suitable model to describe the kinetics of P, K and Mg release data from NEF in water and soil. Pot study ascertained that the nano-enabled fertilizers (nDPF1 and nDPF2) significantly promoted biomass production and nutrient uptake of maize plants as compared to commercial fertilizer treated plants. The present work demonstrated the potential of NEF to increase nutrients uptake efficiency, mitigate moisture retention problem in arid soils and reduce nutrients loss through leaching and safeguard the environment.

Question_2511.Context: Positron emission tomography (PET) is a nuclear medicine functional imaging technique used to observe metabolic processes in the body. The technique uses radiopharmaceuticals that emit positrons, which annihilate with electrons resulting in the emission of gamma rays that are detected by the PET scanner.
Question_2511.Question: What is the primary advantage of using fluorine-18 (18F) over gallium-68 (68Ga) in PET radiopharmaceuticals?
Question_2511.A: Fluorine-18 has a shorter half-life, allowing for quicker imaging.
Question_2511.B: Fluorine-18 has a higher branching fraction and lower average positron energy, resulting in higher resolution images.
Question_2511.C: Fluorine-18 is less radioactive and safer for patients.
Question_2511.D: Fluorine-18 is cheaper and more readily available than gallium-68.
Question_2511.Source: In general, higher resolution images are obtained with fluorine-18 vs gallium-68 due to the differences in their physical decay properties, the former having a higher branching fraction and lower average positron energy.

related_data.Title: Optimized Production of [18F]AlF-P16-093 for Clinical Implementation
related_data.Abstract: Recent advancements in positron emission tomography (PET) using prostate specific membrane antigen (PSMA)-targeted radiopharmaceuticals have changed the standard of care for prostate cancer patients. [68Ga]Ga-P16-093 is a new PSMA-PET radiopharmaceutical that demonstrated superior imaging performance in recent head-to-head studies. This work reports the optimization of the production of [18F]AlF-P16-093 using a custom automated synthesis platform.
related_data.Institute of Origin: Five Eleven Pharma Inc., Philadelphia, PA, USA
related_data.Funding: Funding for research was provided by Five Eleven Pharma.
related_data.Methods: The study utilized a custom automated synthesis platform (PiBOX) for the production of [18F]AlF-P16-093. Optimization studies were conducted to determine the effects of reaction parameters such as time, temperature, and reagent amounts. The optimized method involved a two-step synthesis process with specific conditions for [18F]AlF2+ formation and P16-093 labeling.
related_data.Results: The optimized method enabled the efficient production of [18F]AlF-P16-093 with high radiochemical purity (> 95%) and a none-decay-corrected yield of over 50%. The molar activity was measured at 109 ± 14 GBq/µmole. Stability studies showed a rate of decline in radiochemical purity of ~ 1.4%/h at room temperature, which was reduced to ~ 0.4%/h when stored at 4°C.
related_data.Experiment details: Large-scale production runs of [18F]AlF-P16-093 were carried out using the optimized conditions. The results showed consistent yields and radiochemical purity comparable to low-level optimization runs. Stability studies indicated a decrease in radiochemical purity over time, with slower degradation observed at lower temperatures.

Question_2512.Context: In radiopharmaceutical development, the synthesis of radiotracers often requires optimization of reaction parameters such as time, temperature, and reagent amounts to achieve high radiochemical yield and purity.
Question_2512.Question: What is a key factor that can affect the radiochemical yield of a PET radiotracer during its synthesis?
Question_2512.A: The color of the reaction mixture
Question_2512.B: The brand of the equipment used for synthesis
Question_2512.C: The sensitivity of the radiochemical yield to reaction parameters
Question_2512.D: The time of day when the synthesis is performed
Question_2512.Source: The sensitivity of the radiochemical yield of [18F]AlF-P16-093 to reaction parameters of time, temperature and reagent amounts was investigated using a custom automated system.

related_data.Institute of Origin: Five Eleven Pharma Inc., Philadelphia, PA, USA
related_data.Funding: Funding for research was provided by Five Eleven Pharma.
related_data.Methods: The study utilized a custom automated synthesis platform (PiBOX) for the production of [18F]AlF-P16-093. Optimization studies were conducted to determine the effects of reaction parameters such as time, temperature, and reagent amounts. The optimized method involved a two-step synthesis process with specific conditions for [18F]AlF2+ formation and P16-093 labeling.
related_data.Results: The optimized method enabled the efficient production of [18F]AlF-P16-093 with high radiochemical purity (> 95%) and a none-decay-corrected yield of over 50%. The molar activity was measured at 109 ± 14 GBq/µmole. Stability studies showed a rate of decline in radiochemical purity of ~ 1.4%/h at room temperature, which was reduced to ~ 0.4%/h when stored at 4°C.
related_data.Experiment details: Large-scale production runs of [18F]AlF-P16-093 were carried out using the optimized conditions. The results showed consistent yields and radiochemical purity comparable to low-level optimization runs. Stability studies indicated a decrease in radiochemical purity over time, with slower degradation observed at lower temperatures.

related_data.Title: Immobilization of Thermomyces lanuginosus lipase within a novel hydrogel matrix for enhanced catalytic performance in arbutin lauroylation
related_data.Abstract: The Thermomyces lanuginosus lipase (TLLs) was successfully immobilized within a novel hydrogel matrix through a two-step crosslinking method. TLLs were initially crosslinked through the Schiff base reaction by oxidized carboxymethyl cellulose (OCMC). The water-soluble OCMC@TLLs complex was subsequently crosslinked by carboxymethyl chitosan (CMCSH) in a microfluidic apparatus to form the CMCHS/OCMC@TLLs microspheres. The CD (Circular Dichroism, CD) and FT-IR (Fourier Transform infrared spectroscopy, FT-IR) spectra demonstrated that the crosslinking of TLLs with OCMC resulted in a less significant impact on their structure compared to that with glutaraldehyde. CMCHS/OCMC@TLLs showed decreased catalytic performance due to the mass transfer resistance, while its thermal stability was greatly improved. The CMCHS/OCMC@TLLs were used to catalyze the lauroylation of arbutin in tetrahydrofuran. After 12 h of reaction under optimal conditions, the yield of 6'-O-lauryl arbutin reached an impressive 92.12%. The prepared 6'-O-lauryl arbutin has high lipophilicity and exhibits similar tyrosinase inhibitory activity and higher antioxidant activity compared to its parent compound.
related_data.Institute of Origin: Nanjing Tech University
related_data.Funding: Youth Foundation of Southeast University ChengXian College (z0055)
related_data.Methods: The lipase TLLs were immobilized within a hydrogel matrix through a two-step crosslinking method involving oxidized carboxymethyl cellulose (OCMC) and carboxymethyl chitosan (CMCHS). The immobilization process was characterized using optical microscopy, SEM, FT-IR, and CD spectroscopy. Enzymatic properties such as pH and temperature stability, kinetic parameters, and catalytic performance in arbutin lauroylation were evaluated.
related_data.Results: The immobilized lipase showed enhanced thermal stability and catalytic performance in the lauroylation of arbutin, achieving a high yield of 6'-O-lauryl arbutin. The lipophilic nature of the product and its biological activities were comparable to the parent compound. The hydrogel matrix provided a protective environment for the lipase, improving its stability and performance.
related_data.Experiment details: The study involved the preparation of OCMC/CMCHS@TLLs microspheres using a microfluidic apparatus, characterization of the biocatalysts, evaluation of enzymatic properties, determination of kinetic parameters, and assessment of catalytic performance in arbutin lauroylation.

Question_2698.Context: The oil–water partition coefficient (Log P) is a measure of a compound's hydrophobicity or lipophilicity, with higher values indicating greater lipophilicity.
Question_2698.Question: What does a higher oil–water partition coefficient (Log P) indicate about a compound?
Question_2698.Source: The Log P values of arbutin and 6’-O-lauroyl arbutin were determined in an octanol/water solution with a phase ratio of 1:1. As illustrated in Fig. 9A, the Log P value of α-arbutin was -1.51, indicating its potent hydrophilicity; however, the Log P value of 6’-O-lauroylarbutin was as high as 3.18, demonstrating that the lipophilicity of arbutin was greatly enhanced by introducing a long-chain fatty acyl group.

related_data.Title: Immobilization of Thermomyces lanuginosus lipase within a novel hydrogel matrix for enhanced catalytic performance in arbutin lauroylation
related_data.Abstract: The Thermomyces lanuginosus lipase (TLLs) was successfully immobilized within a novel hydrogel matrix through a two-step crosslinking method. TLLs were initially crosslinked through the Schiff base reaction by oxidized carboxymethyl cellulose (OCMC). The water-soluble OCMC@TLLs complex was subsequently crosslinked by carboxymethyl chitosan (CMCSH) in a microfluidic apparatus to form the CMCHS/OCMC@TLLs microspheres. The CD (Circular Dichroism, CD) and FT-IR (Fourier Transform infrared spectroscopy, FT-IR) spectra demonstrated that the crosslinking of TLLs with OCMC resulted in a less significant impact on their structure compared to that with glutaraldehyde. CMCHS/OCMC@TLLs showed decreased catalytic performance due to the mass transfer resistance, while its thermal stability was greatly improved. The CMCHS/OCMC@TLLs were used to catalyze the lauroylation of arbutin in tetrahydrofuran. After 12 h of reaction under optimal conditions, the yield of 6'-O-lauryl arbutin reached an impressive 92.12%. The prepared 6'-O-lauryl arbutin has high lipophilicity and exhibits similar tyrosinase inhibitory activity and higher antioxidant activity compared to its parent compound.
related_data.Institute of Origin: Nanjing Tech University
related_data.Funding: Youth Foundation of Southeast University ChengXian College (z0055)
related_data.Methods: The lipase TLLs were immobilized within a hydrogel matrix through a two-step crosslinking method involving oxidized carboxymethyl cellulose (OCMC) and carboxymethyl chitosan (CMCHS). The immobilization process was characterized using optical microscopy, SEM, FT-IR, and CD spectroscopy. Enzymatic properties such as pH and temperature stability, kinetic parameters, and catalytic performance in arbutin lauroylation were evaluated.
related_data.Results: The immobilized lipase showed enhanced thermal stability and catalytic performance in the lauroylation of arbutin, achieving a high yield of 6'-O-lauryl arbutin. The lipophilic nature of the product and its biological activities were comparable to the parent compound. The hydrogel matrix provided a protective environment for the lipase, improving its stability and performance.
related_data.Experiment details: The study involved the preparation of OCMC/CMCHS@TLLs microspheres using a microfluidic apparatus, characterization of the biocatalysts, evaluation of enzymatic properties, determination of kinetic parameters, and assessment of catalytic performance in arbutin lauroylation.

Question_2699.Context: Tyrosinase is an enzyme that catalyzes the production of melanin and other pigments from tyrosine by oxidation, and its inhibitors are used in cosmetic products to reduce skin pigmentation.
Question_2699.Question: What is the function of tyrosinase inhibitors in cosmetic products?
Question_2699.D: To protect skin from UV radiation
Question_2699.Source: Thus, it is now widely used in the production of whitening cosmetics. From a structural perspective, arbutin consists of two components, namely, a glucoside and a phenolic group.

Question_2700.Context: DPPH (2,2-diphenyl-1-picrylhydrazyl) is a stable free radical used in assays to measure the antioxidant activity of compounds, where a lower IC50 value indicates stronger antioxidant activity.
Question_2700.Question: In DPPH assays used to measure antioxidant activity, what does a lower IC50 value indicate?
Question_2700.Source: The activity of α-arbutin and 6′-O-lauroylarbutin as anti-oxidants was assessed by the DPPH method. Figure 9C demonstrates that the scavenging rate of all three samples against DPPH radical gradually increases as their concentrations rise, indicating a distinct dose–response relationship.

Question_2751.Context: In plants, cinnamyl alcohol dehydrogenase (CAD) is an enzyme that plays a crucial role in the biosynthesis of lignin by catalyzing the conversion of cinnamaldehydes into their corresponding alcohols.
Question_2751.Question: What is the primary function of cinnamyl alcohol dehydrogenase (CAD) in plants?
Question_2751.A: It assists in the breakdown of starches.
Question_2751.B: It catalyzes the last step of lignin biosynthesis.
Question_2751.C: It aids in the synthesis of chlorophyll.
Question_2751.D: It is involved in the absorption of nutrients from the soil.
Question_2751.Source: Cinnamyl alcohol dehydrogenase (CAD) is a key enzyme in lignin synthesis, which can catalyze the last step of the lignin specific synthesis pathway and play an important regulatory function in lignin biosynthesis.

related_data.Title: Identification and Functional Analysis of the Potato Cinnamyl Alcohol Dehydrogenase (CAD) Gene Family in Response to Cadmium Stress
related_data.Abstract: With the rapid development of the economy and society, soil pollution is becoming more and more serious. Heavy metal cadmium (Cd) pollution is one of the typical problems, which poses a potentially serious threat to crop production and human health. Cinnamyl alcohol dehydrogenase (CAD) is a key enzyme in lignin synthesis and plays an important role in plant resistance to external stress. In this study, combined with bioinformatics analysis and expression pattern analysis, the members of the potato CAD family were identified, and their physical and chemical properties, evolutionary characteristics and chromosome location were clarified, as well as their regulatory effects on Cd tolerance.
related_data.Institute of Origin: Gansu Academy of Agricultural Sciences
related_data.Funding: Doctoral Foundation of Gansu Academy of Agricultural Sciences, National Natural Science Foundation of China, Natural Science Foundation of Gansu Province, Key Project of Modern Agricultural Science and Technology Regional Innovation Center for Support System of Gansu Province
related_data.Methods: Plant materials were subjected to Cd stress treatment, StCAD gene family members were identified using Hidden Markov Models, bioinformatics analysis was conducted, phylogenetic tree construction, physical and chemical properties analysis, subcellular localization prediction, motif analysis, chromosome localization analysis, cis-element analysis, qRT-PCR analysis, and measurement of physiological indices.
related_data.Results: A total of 50 StCAD genes were identified, all located in the cytoplasm. The genes were divided into 6 subfamilies. The promoter region of each StCAD family member contains abiotic stress response elements. Most genes were upregulated after Cd stress, enhancing CAD activity and promoting lignin accumulation in potato roots.
related_data.Experiment details: The study focused on the identification and functional analysis of the potato CAD gene family in response to cadmium stress. Various analyses were conducted to understand the genetic, structural, and functional characteristics of the StCAD genes in potato.

Question_2752.Context: The StCAD gene family in potatoes is divided into subfamilies based on the presence of conserved motifs, which are short, recurring sequence patterns that are often indicative of a protein's function.
Question_2752.Question: Which subfamily of the StCAD gene family in potatoes is characterized by having all conserved motifs except Motif 9?
Question_2752.Source: Among them, subfamily I contained all conserved motifs except Motif 9 which contained more conserved motifs than other subfamilies.

Question_2754.Context: In the analysis of gene promoters, cis-elements are specific DNA sequences that can bind transcription factors and regulate gene expression in response to various stimuli, including stress.
Question_2754.Question: Which type of cis-elements are found in the promoter region of the StCAD gene family related to stress?
Question_2754.Source: The results showed that the 50 CAD genes contained multiple phytohormone response elements, including auxin response element (TGA-element), auxin response element (AuxRR-core), salicylic acid response element (TCA-element), gibberellin response element (GARE-motif), abscisic acid responsive element (ABRE); methyl jasmonate response element (TGACG-motif and CGTCA-motif); methyl jasmonate response element.

Question_2755.C: Most genes were upregulated except for a few

Question_2756.Context: The activities of certain enzymes and the content of compounds like lignin in plants can be altered in response to heavy metal stress, which may reflect the plant's adaptive mechanisms.
Question_2756.Question: What changes were observed in the activities of peroxidase (POD), CAD, and lignin content in potatoes after cadmium (Cd) stress?
Question_2756.A: Decreased POD and CAD activities and lignin content
Question_2756.B: Increased POD and CAD activities and lignin content
Question_2756.C: Decreased POD activity but increased CAD activity and lignin content
Question_2756.D: Increased POD activity but decreased CAD activity and lignin content
Question_2756.Source: The activities of POD, CAD and lignin in potato were significantly changed after Cd stress. The POD activity increased with the increase of Cd stress time, and the POD activity of the T3 treatment was significantly higher than that of other treatments. CAD activity increased significantly after Cd stress and CAD activity of the T0 treatment was significantly lower than that of other treatments. The lignin content showed a gradually increasing trend, and the lignin content of the T0 treatment was the lowest, while that of the T3 treatment was significantly higher than that of T0 and T1.

Question_2757.Question: What role does lignin play in plant growth and stress resistance?
Question_2757.A: It decreases mechanical strength and stress resistance
Question_2757.B: It has no impact on the transport of minerals and water
Question_2757.C: It enhances mechanical strength and stress resistance
Question_2757.D: It only contributes to the defense against biotic stress
Question_2757.Source: Lignin is widely regarded as an important secondary metabolite involved in plant stress resistance, which can enhance the mechanical strength and stress resistance of plants, is conducive to the transport of minerals and water in plants and the defense of an adverse external environment.

Question_2759.Context: The cis-elements in the promoter regions of genes are indicative of the gene's potential functions and responses to various stimuli, including abiotic stress.
Question_2759.Question: What do the cis-elements in the promoter regions of the StCAD gene family suggest about their functions?
Question_2759.A: They are involved in fruit ripening
Question_2759.B: They play a role in flower coloration
Question_2759.C: They are related to growth and development
Question_2759.D: They may play an important role in response to abiotic stress
Question_2759.Source: The cis-element analysis of potato CAD family genes showed that the promoter region was rich in cis-elements related to plant response to stress, including metal response elements, salicylic acid response elements and abscisic acid response elements, suggesting that it may play an important role in response to abiotic stress.

related_data.Funding: Doctoral Foundation of Gansu Academy of Agricultural Sciences, National Natural Science Foundation of China, Natural Science Foundation of Gansu Province, Key Project of Modern Agricultural Science and Technology Regional Innovation Center for Support System of Gansu Province
related_data.Methods: Plant materials were subjected to Cd stress treatment, StCAD gene family members were identified using Hidden Markov Models, bioinformatics analysis was conducted, phylogenetic tree construction, physical and chemical properties analysis, subcellular localization prediction, motif analysis, chromosome localization analysis, cis-element analysis, qRT-PCR analysis, and measurement of physiological indices.
related_data.Results: A total of 50 StCAD genes were identified, all located in the cytoplasm. The genes were divided into 6 subfamilies. The promoter region of each StCAD family member contains abiotic stress response elements. Most genes were upregulated after Cd stress, enhancing CAD activity and promoting lignin accumulation in potato roots.
related_data.Experiment details: The study focused on the identification and functional analysis of the potato CAD gene family in response to cadmium stress. Various analyses were conducted to understand the genetic, structural, and functional characteristics of the StCAD genes in potato.

Question_2771.Context: Plant parasitic nematodes are harmful to agricultural production and can be controlled by nematode-trapping fungi, which capture nematodes using specialized traps.

Question_2771.A: They enhance the growth of plant parasitic nematodes
Question_2771.B: They capture nematodes to control their population
Question_2771.C: They have no significant role in agriculture
Question_2771.D: They promote infection of plants by pathogenic microorganisms
Question_2771.Source: Nematode-trapping fungi (NTF) form diverse special traps to capture nematodes through mycelium specialization, such as three-dimensional networks, adhesive knobs, and constricting rings etc.

related_data.Title: Induction of trap formation in Arthrobotrys oligospora by Pseudomonas lurida and identification of active metabolites
related_data.Abstract: Plant parasitic nematodes (PPNs) cause serious harm to agricultural production. Nematode-trapping fungi (NTF) can produce traps to capture nematodes and are the main resource for controlling nematodes. Pseudomonas lurida is widely existed in different habitats, which produces active metabolites to induce trap formation of Arthrobotrys oligospora, a famous NTF. To further identify the active substances, metabolic regulation was carried out in the strain by molecular biological methods. A mutant strain P. lurida araC-PoprL with abundant secondary metabolites was constructed, and 19 metabolites (1-19) including a new compound, 1,1-dimethyl-1,3,4,9-tetrahydropyrano[3,4-b]indole-3-carboxylic acid (1), were isolated and identified. The activity assay showed that 1-methylhydantoin (9) could effectively induce A. oligospora to produce traps.

related_data.Institute of Origin: Yunnan University
related_data.Funding: National Key Research and Development Program, National Natural Science Foundation of China, Department of Science and Technology of Yunnan Province
related_data.Methods: Equipments used for analysis, strains and nematode cultivation methods, determination of induced activity of fermentation broth and extract, overexpression of the araC gene in P. lurida, LC‒MS detection of metabolites, extraction and isolation of secondary metabolites from P. lurida araC-PoprL
related_data.Results: Induction of trap formation in A. oligospora by P. lurida, comparison of metabolites of P. lurida araC-PoprL with WT, structural identification of compounds, determination of induced activity of isolated metabolites
related_data.Experiment details: Study on the interaction between P. lurida and A. oligospora, identification of new metabolites, evaluation of inducement activity of isolated compounds

Question_3011.Context: Arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi (AMF) can establish symbiotic relationships with most terrestrial plants, facilitating nutrient and water uptake for the plant.
Question_3011.Question: What is the primary role of arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi (AMF) in their symbiotic relationship with terrestrial plants?
Question_3011.A: To decompose organic matter in the soil
Question_3011.B: To facilitate nutrient and water uptake for the plant
Question_3011.C: To protect the plant from herbivores
Question_3011.D: To produce phytohormones for plant growth
Question_3011.Source: AMF are a widely distributed group of soil fungi that can establish symbiosis with most terrestrial plants, including citrus. AMF can promote growth performance, nutrient acquisition, and stress tolerance of the host plant, as well as crop yield and quality.

related_data.Title: Root Mycorrhizal Colonization Process of Trifoliate Orange and Responsive Patterns of Plant Growth, Root Peroxide Hydrogen, Antioxidant Enzymes, and Transporter Protein Gene Expression
related_data.Abstract: Arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi (AMF) trigger beneficial effects on their hosts, but it is unknown how plants modulate their defense responses during root colonization of AMF and the symbiotic benefits are initiated. The purpose of this study was to analyze the root mycorrhizal colonization process of trifoliate orange and the responsive patterns of plant growth, root peroxide hydrogen (H2O2), antioxidant enzymes and their encoding gene expression, and sugar, lipid and phosphate transporter protein gene expression at 7‒56 days of inoculation (doi) with Funneliformis mosseae (Fm). Fm developed appressoriums on the root surface at 7 doi, followed by abundant arbuscules in root cortical cells at 28 doi, intracellular vesicles at 42 doi, and root mycorrhizal colonization rate of 41.54% at 56 doi. Plant growth improvement by Fm started at 28 doi. The immune defense response of roots was initiated at 7 doi, as evidenced by the increase of H2O2 levels and superoxide dismutase (SOD), peroxidase (POD), and catalase (CAT) activity, as well as the up‑regulation of PtMn-SOD, PtCu/Zn-SOD, PtPOD, and PtCAT expression, which lasted until 14 doi. Starting at 28 doi, a sugar transporter gene (PtSWEET), a lipid transporter gene (PtSTR), and a phosphate transporter gene (PtPT6) were initiated to be up‑regulated, followed by the up‑regulation of PtSTR2, PtPT3, and PtPT5 at 42 doi and PtFe-SOD at 56 doi. Arbuscule formation and plant growth improvement together at 28 doi suggested that arbuscules trigger improved growth responses of host plants. This study also reveals the initiation of host immune defense response and function in early root AMF colonization.
related_data.Journal: Chemical Biology and Technology in Agriculture
related_data.Institute of Origin: College of Horticulture and Gardening, Yangtze University, Hubei, China
related_data.Funding: Scientific and Technological Innovation Team of Outstanding Young Scientists, Hubei Provincial Department of Education (T201604)
related_data.Methods: The study involved analyzing the root mycorrhizal colonization process of trifoliate orange and the responsive patterns of plant growth, root peroxide hydrogen (H2O2), antioxidant enzymes and their encoding gene expression, and sugar, lipid and phosphate transporter protein gene expression at 7‒56 days of inoculation with Funneliformis mosseae (Fm). The experiment included preparation of AMF inoculum, plant culture and experimental design, determination of plant growth and root mycorrhizal colonization, determination of root H2O2 concentrations, determination of root antioxidant enzyme activities, and analysis of relative expression of genes.
related_data.Results: The study found that Fm colonization of trifoliate orange roots led to the development of appressoriums, arbuscules, and intracellular vesicles, with a root mycorrhizal colonization rate of 41.54% at 56 days of inoculation. Plant growth improvement by Fm was observed starting at 28 days of inoculation. The immune defense response of roots was initiated at 7 days of inoculation, with increased levels of H2O2 and antioxidant enzyme activities. Gene expression analysis revealed up-regulation of antioxidant enzyme genes, sugar transporter gene, lipid transporter genes, and phosphate transporter genes at different time points during the colonization process.
related_data.Experiment details: The experiment involved the inoculation of trifoliate orange seedlings with Funneliformis mosseae and monitoring the root colonization process and plant responses over a period of 56 days. Various parameters such as plant growth, root H2O2 levels, antioxidant enzyme activities, and gene expression were measured at different time points to understand the dynamics of the symbiotic relationship between the plant and the mycorrhizal fungus.

Question_3017.Context: Mycorrhizal colonization involves the formation of structures such as arbuscules and vesicles within the root cortical cells, which are important for the symbiotic relationship.
Question_3017.Question: What structures are formed within the root cortical cells during mycorrhizal colonization?
Question_3017.Source: Under the action of signaling molecules, fungal hyphae contact the surface of root epidermal cells and/or root hairs to form an appressorium, and enter the roots, where fungal hyphae colonize the cortical cells of roots, some of which continuously remifying and fill a cortical cell to form a complex tree-like structure, the arbuscule.

Question_3018.Context: The symbiotic relationship between AMF and plants involves a bidirectional exchange of nutrients, where plants provide carbon sources to the fungi.
Question_3018.Question: In the symbiotic relationship between AMF and plants, what do plants provide to the fungi?
Question_3018.Source: Arbuscular mycorrhizae are manifested by a bidirectional exchange at the symbiotic interface, where the host plant provides carbon sources (fatty acids and sugars) to the arbuscular mycorrhizal fungus.

Question_3019.Context: The process of mycorrhizal colonization in plant roots is marked by the formation of appressorium, which is an early structure in the establishment of the symbiotic relationship.
Question_3019.Question: What is an appressorium in the context of mycorrhizal colonization?
Question_3019.A: A storage structure for nutrients within the root cells
Question_3019.B: An early structure formed on the root surface for fungal entry
Question_3019.C: A transport channel for water and minerals in the root
Question_3019.D: A protective barrier against soil pathogens
Question_3019.Source: AMF colonization of plant roots starts with the germination of fungal spores in the soil, followed by the continuous growth of hyphae. Under the action of signaling molecules, fungal hyphae contact the surface of root epidermal cells and/or root hairs to form an appressorium.

Question_3020.Source: Starting at 28 doi, a sugar transporter gene (PtSWEET), a lipid transporter gene (PtSTR), and a phosphate transporter gene (PtPT6) were initiated to be up-regulated, followed by the up-regulation of PtSTR2, PtPT3, and PtPT5 at 42 doi and PtFe-SOD at 56 doi.

related_data.Title: Root Mycorrhizal Colonization Process of Trifoliate Orange and Responsive Patterns of Plant Growth, Root Peroxide Hydrogen, Antioxidant Enzymes, and Transporter Protein Gene Expression
related_data.Abstract: Arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi (AMF) trigger beneficial effects on their hosts, but it is unknown how plants modulate their defense responses during root colonization of AMF and the symbiotic benefits are initiated. The purpose of this study was to analyze the root mycorrhizal colonization process of trifoliate orange and the responsive patterns of plant growth, root peroxide hydrogen (H2O2), antioxidant enzymes and their encoding gene expression, and sugar, lipid and phosphate transporter protein gene expression at 7‒56 days of inoculation (doi) with Funneliformis mosseae (Fm). Fm developed appressoriums on the root surface at 7 doi, followed by abundant arbuscules in root cortical cells at 28 doi, intracellular vesicles at 42 doi, and root mycorrhizal colonization rate of 41.54% at 56 doi. Plant growth improvement by Fm started at 28 doi. The immune defense response of roots was initiated at 7 doi, as evidenced by the increase of H2O2 levels and superoxide dismutase (SOD), peroxidase (POD), and catalase (CAT) activity, as well as the up‑regulation of PtMn-SOD, PtCu/Zn-SOD, PtPOD, and PtCAT expression, which lasted until 14 doi. Starting at 28 doi, a sugar transporter gene (PtSWEET), a lipid transporter gene (PtSTR), and a phosphate transporter gene (PtPT6) were initiated to be up‑regulated, followed by the up‑regulation of PtSTR2, PtPT3, and PtPT5 at 42 doi and PtFe-SOD at 56 doi. Arbuscule formation and plant growth improvement together at 28 doi suggested that arbuscules trigger improved growth responses of host plants. This study also reveals the initiation of host immune defense response and function in early root AMF colonization.
related_data.Journal: Chemical Biology and Technology in Agriculture
related_data.Institute of Origin: College of Horticulture and Gardening, Yangtze University, Hubei, China
related_data.Funding: Scientific and Technological Innovation Team of Outstanding Young Scientists, Hubei Provincial Department of Education (T201604)
related_data.Methods: The study involved analyzing the root mycorrhizal colonization process of trifoliate orange and the responsive patterns of plant growth, root peroxide hydrogen (H2O2), antioxidant enzymes and their encoding gene expression, and sugar, lipid and phosphate transporter protein gene expression at 7‒56 days of inoculation with Funneliformis mosseae (Fm). The experiment included preparation of AMF inoculum, plant culture and experimental design, determination of plant growth and root mycorrhizal colonization, determination of root H2O2 concentrations, determination of root antioxidant enzyme activities, and analysis of relative expression of genes.
related_data.Results: The study found that Fm colonization of trifoliate orange roots led to the development of appressoriums, arbuscules, and intracellular vesicles, with a root mycorrhizal colonization rate of 41.54% at 56 days of inoculation. Plant growth improvement by Fm was observed starting at 28 days of inoculation. The immune defense response of roots was initiated at 7 days of inoculation, with increased levels of H2O2 and antioxidant enzyme activities. Gene expression analysis revealed up-regulation of antioxidant enzyme genes, sugar transporter gene, lipid transporter genes, and phosphate transporter genes at different time points during the colonization process.
related_data.Experiment details: The experiment involved the inoculation of trifoliate orange seedlings with Funneliformis mosseae and monitoring the root colonization process and plant responses over a period of 56 days. Various parameters such as plant growth, root H2O2 levels, antioxidant enzyme activities, and gene expression were measured at different time points to understand the dynamics of the symbiotic relationship between the plant and the mycorrhizal fungus.

Question_3031.Context: Watery kimchi is a type of Korean kimchi that is prepared with added water or brine solution during the fermentation process and is usually consumed as a soup.
Question_3031.Question: Which type of watery kimchi was found to have the highest total carotenoid content?
Question_3031.Source: Of the three kimchi types, YMK had the highest total carotenoid content (63.78 ± 4.88 mg/100 g), and DC had the lowest (3.50 ± 0.12 mg/100 g).

related_data.Title: Bioactive Compounds and Antioxidant Activities of Watery Kimchi
related_data.Abstract: Watery kimchi is a traditional fermented food served with its soup. In this study, we collected 21 samples of yeolmu mul kimchi (YMK), dongchimi (DC), and nabak kimchi (NK), respectively, which are the most popular watery kimchi in Korea. A composite sample of each watery kimchi was prepared for estimation of their bioactive compounds and antioxidant activities. YMK had the highest total carotenoid content (63.78 ± 4.88 mg/100 g, of which lutein, capsanthin, and β-carotene were the main carotenoids), and DC had the lowest (3.50 ± 0.12 mg/100 g). YMK also had the highest contents of chlorophyll (250.1 ± 3.91 mg/100 g), ascorbic acid (447.16 ± 8.95 mg/100 g), and capsaicinoids (2.51 ± 0.09 mg/100 g) compared to DC and NK. The lactic acid content was highest in NK (582.72 ± 29.10 mg/100 g). Moreover, YMK showed significantly higher antioxidant activity (ABTS and DPPH) than DC and NK. The results highlighted watery kimchi as a potentially valuable source of bioactive compounds, providing 4.11% of the recommended daily intake of vitamin A according to the 2020 Korean dietary reference intakes.
related_data.Institute of Origin: Chung-Ang University, Republic of Korea
related_data.Funding: Chung-Ang University Graduate Research Scholarship
related_data.Methods: The study collected 21 samples of watery kimchi and prepared composite samples for analysis of bioactive compounds and antioxidant activities. Carotenoids, chlorophylls, capsaicinoids, lactic acid, and ascorbic acid were extracted and quantified using various analytical methods. Antioxidant activities were measured using ABTS and DPPH radical scavenging assays.
related_data.Results: YMK exhibited the highest total carotenoid content, chlorophyll content, ascorbic acid content, and capsaicinoid content among the watery kimchi samples. YMK also showed the highest antioxidant activity compared to DC and NK. The study highlighted the potential health benefits of watery kimchi as a source of bioactive compounds and antioxidants.
related_data.Experiment details: The experiment involved the collection and analysis of watery kimchi samples to determine their bioactive compound content and antioxidant activities. The results indicated that YMK had superior nutritional and antioxidant properties compared to DC and NK.

related_data.Title: Regulation of Nitric Oxide on Fungal Secondary Metabolite Biosynthesis in Shiraia sp. S9 Exposed to Red Light
related_data.Abstract: Perylenequinones (PQs) from bambusicolous Shiraia fungi serve as excellent photosensitizers for photodynamic therapy. However, the lower yield of PQ production in mycelium cultures is an important bottleneck for their clinical application. Light has long been recognized as a pivotal regulatory signal for fungal secondary metabolite biosynthesis. In this study, we explored the role of nitric oxide (NO) in the growth and PQ biosynthesis in mycelium cultures of Shiraia sp. S9 exposed to red light. The continuous irradiation with red light (627 nm, 200 lx) suppressed fungal conidiation, promoted hyphal branching, and elicited a notable increase in PQ accumulation. Red light exposure induced NO generation, peaking to 81.7 μmol/g FW on day 8 of the culture, with the involvement of nitric oxide synthase (NOS)- or nitrate reductase (NR)-dependent pathways. The application of a NO donor sodium nitroprusside (SNP) restored conidiation of Shiraia sp. S9 under red light and stimulated PQ production, which was mitigated upon the introduction of NO scavenger carboxy-PTIO or soluble guanylate cyclase inhibitor NS-2028. These results showed that red light-induced NO, as a signaling molecule, was involved in the regulation of growth and PQ production in Shiraia sp. S9 through the NO-cGMP-PKG signaling pathway. While mycelial H2O2 content exhibited no significant alternations, a transient increase of intracellular Ca2+ and extracellular ATP (eATP) content was detected upon exposure to red light. The generation of NO was found to be interdependent on cytosolic Ca2+ and eATP concentration. These signal molecules cooperated synergistically to enhance membrane permeability and elevate the transcript levels of PQ biosynthetic genes in Shiraia sp. S9. Notably, the combined treatment of red light with 5 μM SNP yielded a synergistic effect, resulting in a substantially higher level of hypocrellin A (HA, 254 mg/L), about 3.0-fold over the dark control. Our findings provide valuable insights into the regulation of NO on fungal secondary metabolite biosynthesis and present a promising strategy involving the combined elicitation with SNP for enhanced production of photoactive PQs and other valuable secondary metabolites in fungi.
related_data.Institute of Origin: Soochow University, Suzhou, China
related_data.Funding: National Natural Science Foundation of China (No. 82073955 and 81773696), Priority Academic Program Development of the Jiangsu Higher Education Institutes (PAPD)

The continuous irradiation with red light (627 nm, 200 lx) was used to suppress fungal conidiation, promote hyphal branching, and elicit an increase in PQ accumulation. The involvement of nitric oxide synthase (NOS) and nitrate reductase (NR) pathways in NO generation was investigated. The application of a NO donor sodium nitroprusside (SNP) and NO scavenger carboxy-PTIO or soluble guanylate cyclase inhibitor NS-2028 was used to study the effects on conidiation and PQ production. Intracellular Ca2+ and extracellular ATP (eATP) content were measured to understand their interdependence on NO generation. The synergistic effect of red light and SNP on HA production was evaluated.
related_data.Results: Red light exposure induced NO generation in Shiraia sp. S9, peaking at 81.7 μmol/g FW on day 8 of the culture. The application of SNP restored conidiation and stimulated PQ production, while the introduction of NO scavenger or sGC inhibitor mitigated these effects. The combined treatment of red light with SNP resulted in a 3.0-fold increase in HA production compared to the dark control. related_data.Experiment details: The fungal strain Shiraia sp. S9 was isolated and maintained on potato dextrose agar (PDA) slants. Liquid cultures were exposed to red light (627 nm, 200 lx) for 8 days at 28 °C. NO generation was determined using the NO-specific fluorescent probe DAF-2 DA. NOS and NR activity, cGMP content, and gene expression levels related to PQ biosynthesis were analyzed. The effects of eATP and Ca2+ signals on NO production were investigated. The impact of NO on fungal growth, development, membrane permeability, and PQ biosynthesis under red light exposure was assessed.

Question_3156.Context: Hypocrellin A, a type of perylenequinone, is known for its strong photodynamic effects and is advantageous for biomedical applications due to its high yields of reactive oxygen species.
Question_3156.Question: What are the advantages of Hypocrellin A for biomedical applications?
Question_3156.A: High yields of reactive nitrogen species
Question_3156.D: High yields of reactive oxygen species
Question_3156.Source: Hypocrellin A (HA), a type of hypocrellins, exhibits strong photodynamic effects on tumor cells and microbial pathogens when exposed to visible light and oxygen. It has advantages such as high yields of reactive oxygen species (ROS), low dark toxicity, and rapid metabolism for the biomedical application.

Question_3157.Context: Fungal secondary metabolites can be produced through biotechnological alternatives such as mycelium cultures, which can be a solution to the challenges in artificial cultivation and chemical synthesis.

Question_3157.Source: However, due to difficulties in artificial cultivation of the fruiting body and challenges in chemical synthesis of PQs like hypocrellins, Shiraia mycelium cultures have emerged as a biotechnological alternative for PQ production.

related_data.Methods: The study explored the role of nitric oxide (NO) in the growth and perylenequinone (PQ) biosynthesis in mycelium cultures of Shiraia sp. S9 exposed to red light. The continuous irradiation with red light (627 nm, 200 lx) was used to suppress fungal conidiation, promote hyphal branching, and elicit an increase in PQ accumulation. The involvement of nitric oxide synthase (NOS) and nitrate reductase (NR) pathways in NO generation was investigated. The application of a NO donor sodium nitroprusside (SNP) and NO scavenger carboxy-PTIO or soluble guanylate cyclase inhibitor NS-2028 was used to study the effects on conidiation and PQ production. Intracellular Ca2+ and extracellular ATP (eATP) content were measured to understand their interdependence on NO generation. The synergistic effect of red light and SNP on HA production was evaluated.
related_data.Results: Red light exposure induced NO generation in Shiraia sp. S9, peaking at 81.7 μmol/g FW on day 8 of the culture. The application of SNP restored conidiation and stimulated PQ production, while the introduction of NO scavenger or sGC inhibitor mitigated these effects. The combined treatment of red light with SNP resulted in a 3.0-fold increase in HA production compared to the dark control. The study provided insights into the regulatory role of NO on fungal secondary metabolite biosynthesis and presented a promising strategy for enhanced production of photoactive PQs and other valuable secondary metabolites in fungi.
related_data.Experiment details: The fungal strain Shiraia sp. S9 was isolated and maintained on potato dextrose agar (PDA) slants. Liquid cultures were exposed to red light (627 nm, 200 lx) for 8 days at 28 °C. NO generation was determined using the NO-specific fluorescent probe DAF-2 DA. NOS and NR activity, cGMP content, and gene expression levels related to PQ biosynthesis were analyzed. The effects of eATP and Ca2+ signals on NO production were investigated. The impact of NO on fungal growth, development, membrane permeability, and PQ biosynthesis under red light exposure was assessed.

Question_3158.Context: Red light has been shown to significantly promote the production of certain fungal metabolites, which is an example of how environmental signals can influence the biosynthesis of secondary metabolites.
Question_3158.Question: What effect does red light have on the production of certain fungal metabolites?
Question_3158.Source: Red light has been recognized as an essential environmental signal that facilitates the production of fungal metabolites, such as exo- and endo- polysaccharides of Ganoderma lucidum (Poyedinok et al. 2008), mycophenolic acid of Penicillium brevicompactum (Shu et al. 2010), and fumonisin B1-B3 of Fusarium verticillioides (Fanelli et al. 2012).

related_data.Title: Regulation of Nitric Oxide on Fungal Secondary Metabolite Biosynthesis in Shiraia sp. S9 Exposed to Red Light
related_data.Abstract: Perylenequinones (PQs) from bambusicolous Shiraia fungi serve as excellent photosensitizers for photodynamic therapy. However, the lower yield of PQ production in mycelium cultures is an important bottleneck for their clinical application. Light has long been recognized as a pivotal regulatory signal for fungal secondary metabolite biosynthesis. In this study, we explored the role of nitric oxide (NO) in the growth and PQ biosynthesis in mycelium cultures of Shiraia sp. S9 exposed to red light. The continuous irradiation with red light (627 nm, 200 lx) suppressed fungal conidiation, promoted hyphal branching, and elicited a notable increase in PQ accumulation. Red light exposure induced NO generation, peaking to 81.7 μmol/g FW on day 8 of the culture, with the involvement of nitric oxide synthase (NOS)- or nitrate reductase (NR)-dependent pathways. The application of a NO donor sodium nitroprusside (SNP) restored conidiation of Shiraia sp. S9 under red light and stimulated PQ production, which was mitigated upon the introduction of NO scavenger carboxy-PTIO or soluble guanylate cyclase inhibitor NS-2028. These results showed that red light-induced NO, as a signaling molecule, was involved in the regulation of growth and PQ production in Shiraia sp. S9 through the NO-cGMP-PKG signaling pathway. While mycelial H2O2 content exhibited no significant alternations, a transient increase of intracellular Ca2+ and extracellular ATP (eATP) content was detected upon exposure to red light. The generation of NO was found to be interdependent on cytosolic Ca2+ and eATP concentration. These signal molecules cooperated synergistically to enhance membrane permeability and elevate the transcript levels of PQ biosynthetic genes in Shiraia sp. S9. Notably, the combined treatment of red light with 5 μM SNP yielded a synergistic effect, resulting in a substantially higher level of hypocrellin A (HA, 254 mg/L), about 3.0-fold over the dark control. Our findings provide valuable insights into the regulation of NO on fungal secondary metabolite biosynthesis and present a promising strategy involving the combined elicitation with SNP for enhanced production of photoactive PQs and other valuable secondary metabolites in fungi.

Question_3159.Context: The signaling molecule nitric oxide (NO) can be generated in fungi during exposure to light, and this generation can be upregulated by certain types of light exposure.
Question_3159.Question: What can upregulate the generation of nitric oxide in fungi?
Question_3159.Source: NO generation was also observed in fungi during light exposure, such as in Trichophyton rubrum, where intense pulsed light at 420 nm upregulated nitric oxide synthase (NOS) to synthesize NO, leading to fungal growth inhibition.

Question_3421.Context: Microbial agents and organic fertilizers can influence the physical properties and fertility of rhizosphere soil, which in turn can affect plant growth.

related_data.Title: Analysis of exogenous lactic acid bacteria on growth and development of different herbaceous peony varieties and rhizosphere soil nutrients
related_data.Abstract: Correction: Analysis of exogenous lactic acid bacteria on growth and development of different herbaceous peony varieties and rhizosphere soil nutrients. The study investigates the influence of lactic acid bacteria on rhizosphere soil nutrients and organic matter content, soil enzyme activity, free salicylic acid content, herbaceous peony root physiology, antioxidant oxidase activity, root MDA content, root vitality, osmotic adjustment substance content, root system phytohormone and spermidine content, and root system paeoniflorin content.

Question_3491.Context: In pharmacokinetics, models are used to simulate the distribution of pharmaceuticals among different organs in the body. Each organ can be treated as a collection of compartments, each associated with a different spatial structure of the organs, such as vascular structure, interstitial space, and the internal space of cells.
Question_3491.Question: What governs the interchange of material between compartments in pharmacokinetic models?
Question_3491.Source: Each organ is treated as a collection of compartments, each associated with a different spacial structure of the organs (i.e. vascular structure, interstitial space, PSMA binding sites, and the internal space of cells). The interchange of material between these compartments is governed by ordinary differential equations (ODE).

related_data.Title: Development of a Physiologically Based Radiopharmacokinetic Model for Radiopharmaceutical Therapies
related_data.Abstract: We aimed to develop a publicly shared computational physiologically based pharmacokinetic (PBPK) model to reliably simulate and analyze radiopharmaceutical therapies (RPTs), including probing of hot-cold ligand competitions as well as alternative injection scenarios and drug designs, towards optimal therapies. To handle the complexity of PBPK models, a scalable modeling notation called the “reaction graph” is introduced, enabling easy inclusion of various interactions. Physiologically based radiopharmacokinetic (PBRPK) modeling was fine-tuned specifically for radiopharmaceuticals. Three important applications were studied using the PBRPK model: studying the effect of competition between hot and cold species on delivered doses to tumors and organs at risk, evaluating an alternative paradigm of utilizing multi-bolus injections in RPTs instead of prevalent single injections, and studying the impact of varying albumin-binding affinities by ligands and the implications for RPTs. Advanced computational PBRPK modeling enables simulation and analysis of a variety of intervention and drug design scenarios towards more optimal delivery of RPTs.
related_data.Institute of Origin: University of British Columbia, Vancouver, BC, Canada
related_data.Funding: This work was supported by [Funding Source].
related_data.Methods: The PBPK model structure developed by Kletting et al. (2016) was used as a baseline model for the kinetics of 177Lu-PSMA. The model was expanded and made more scalable to enable detailed interactions of radiopharmaceuticals with other species. The model was implemented in MATLAB Simbiology using population-measured values for model parameters. Different variations of parameters were used to represent 'virtual patients'.
related_data.Results: The scalable model implementation in Simbiology Matlab had a run time of 0.15 ± 0.2 seconds to generate time activity curves for more than 18 organs for about 50,000 minutes. The model was shared in SBML format. Results showed the effects of competition between hot and cold species, the impact of tumor receptor densities and volumes, and the effectiveness of multi-bolus injections on delivered doses to tumors.
related_data.Experiment details: The study focused on developing a physiologically based radiopharmacokinetic model for radiopharmaceutical therapies, with a specific emphasis on hot-cold ligand competitions, alternative injection scenarios, and drug designs. The model was fine-tuned for radiopharmaceuticals and used to study the impact of various factors on delivered doses to tumors and organs at risk.

Question_3492.Context: In the context of radiopharmaceutical therapies, the term 'hot' refers to molecules labeled with radioisotopes, whereas 'cold' refers to unlabeled molecules. These molecules compete for binding sites, which can affect the delivered dose to tumors and organs at risk.
Question_3492.Question: What is the effect of increasing the number of cold molecules on the delivered dose to the tumor when the amount of injected hot activity is fixed?
Question_3492.C: Has no effect on the delivered dose
Question_3492.D: Changes the type of radiation emitted
Question_3492.Source: In Fig. 1 we observe that for a fixed amount of injected activity (i.e. fixed hot amount), increasing the number of cold molecules (i.e. decreasing specific activities, and moving up on the dashed line in Fig. 1), will result in lower delivered doses to the tumor.

Question_3493.Context: The concept of 'twist' in pharmacokinetic modeling is a geometrical measure used to describe the tilt of iso-dose curves, which represent the relationship between injected activities and delivered doses to tumors.
Question_3493.Question: What does a decreasing 'twist' value indicate in the context of iso-dose curves for tumors?
Question_3493.A: Increased competition between hot and cold species
Question_3493.B: Decreased competition between hot and cold species
Question_3493.C: Constant competition regardless of injected activities
Question_3493.D: Iso-dose curves are not related to competition between species
Question_3493.Source: Furthermore, the figure shows that moving from the iso-dose curve corresponding to the lowest dose (the leftmost) to the iso-dose curve with the highest dose value (the rightmost), the curves become more horizontal. Figures 2 and 3 show the effects of varying tumor receptor densities and tumor volumes on the tumor absorbed doses, respectively. It is observed that by increasing the tumor receptor density or tumor volume, the average delivered dose to the tumor increases. Furthermore, in doing so, the iso-dose curves become less tilted (horizontal) as we move from the iso-dose curve with the lowest dose value to the one with the highest dose value.

Question_3494.Context: In radiopharmaceutical therapies, multi-bolus injection refers to the administration of the therapeutic agent in smaller portions over time, as opposed to a single bolus injection where the entire dose is administered at once.
Question_3494.Question: What is the effect of fractionating injections (multi-bolus) compared to a single bolus injection on the delivered dose to the tumor?
Question_3494.C: Has no effect on the delivered dose
Question_3494.D: Changes the type of radiation emitted
Question_3494.Source: These figures show that under a fixed tumor volume or tumor receptor density, more fractionation (higher number of injections or higher time between injections) translates to a higher delivered dose to the tumor.

Question_3495.Context: In pharmacokinetic models, the parameter 'Kd' refers to the dissociation constant, which is an indicator of the affinity between a ligand and a protein such as albumin. A lower Kd value indicates a higher affinity.
Question_3495.Question: How does an increased albumin-binding affinity (lower Kd) affect the blood residence time of radiopharmaceuticals?
Question_3495.C: Has no effect on the blood residence time
Question_3495.D: Causes immediate clearance from the blood
Question_3495.Source: Figure 9 shows that the blood residence time is increased with a higher affinity of the radiopharmaceutical to the albumin.

Question_3496.Context: The 'enhancement factor' in pharmacokinetic modeling is a metric used to quantify the effectiveness of a therapeutic intervention, such as the binding of a ligand to albumin, in delivering a differential dose to a target organ relative to other organs.
Question_3496.Question: What does an enhancement factor greater than one signify in the context of albumin binding in radiopharmaceutical therapies?
Question_3496.A: Decreased dose delivery to the tumor
Question_3496.B: Increased dose delivery to organs at risk
Question_3496.C: Increased differential dose delivery to the tumor
Question_3496.D: No change in dose delivery to any organ
Question_3496.Source: Intuitively speaking, EF quantifies the effectiveness of albumin binding in delivering differential dose to tumor (relative to OAR). For instance, for a given value of K alb D , EF = 4 means that enabling albumin binding with the given K alb D , delivered 4 times more dose to the tumor relative to OAR, compared to the situation where albumin binding was off (i.e. K alb D = ∞).

Question_3497.Context: In radiopharmaceutical therapies, the term 'specific activity' refers to the amount of radioactivity per unit mass of a compound, indicating the proportion of 'hot' (radioactive) to 'cold' (non-radioactive) molecules.
Question_3497.Question: What is the relationship between specific activity and the delivered dose to a tumor when the amount of injected hot activity is fixed?
Question_3497.A: Higher specific activity increases the delivered dose
Question_3497.B: Lower specific activity increases the delivered dose
Question_3497.C: Specific activity has no effect on the delivered dose
Question_3497.D: Specific activity only affects the type of radiation emitted
Question_3497.Source: In Fig. 1 we observe that for a fixed amount of injected activity (i.e. fixed hot amount), increasing the number of cold molecules (i.e. decreasing specific activities, and moving up on the dashed line in Fig. 1), will result in lower delivered doses to the tumor.

Question_3498.Context: In pharmacokinetic modeling, the term 'tumor sink effect' refers to the phenomenon where a tumor with certain characteristics, such as a larger volume or higher receptor density, can absorb more of the administered therapeutic agent, potentially affecting the distribution to other organs.
Question_3498.Question: How does an increase in tumor volume affect the competition between hot and cold species for binding sites?
Question_3498.C: Has no effect on competition in the tumor
Question_3498.D: Only affects competition in organs at risk
Question_3498.Source: Furthermore, in doing so, the iso-dose curves become less tilted (horizontal) as we move from the iso-dose curve with the lowest dose value to the one with the highest dose value. This translates to the decreasing 'twist' value is shown in Figs. 4 and 5. Overall, tumor receptors and volumes have an important interplay with injected radioactivities and specific activities.

Question_3500.Context: In the context of radiopharmaceutical therapies, the term 'time-integrated activity' (TIA) refers to the total amount of radioactivity that an organ is exposed to over a period of time, which is directly related to the absorbed dose.
Question_3500.Question: What does the term 'maximum relative TIA change' (MRDC) represent in pharmacokinetic modeling?
Question_3500.A: The change in TIA due to variations in temperature
Question_3500.B: The change in TIA due to variations in organ size
Question_3500.C: The maximum change in TIA relative to a baseline injection strategy
Question_3500.D: The change in TIA due to variations in radiation type
Question_3500.Source: To quantify the effect of multi-bolus injection in contrast to the single bolus injection, we found the injection strategy yielding the highest delivered dose to each organ and tumor, and then calculated the relative change in dose compared to the bolus injection (we call it the maximum relative dose change or MRDC). Note that since dose and TIA are different up to a multiplicative constant, the maximum relative dose change is the same as the maximum relative TIA change.

Question_3741.Context: Automated dispensing systems (ADS) are used to dispense radiopharmaceuticals while reducing radiation exposure, improving dose accuracy, and limiting microbiological contamination.
Question_3741.Question: What is the maximum acceptable bias for the accuracy of an automated dispensing system when dispensing radiopharmaceuticals?
Question_3741.Source: The maximum bias is 2.35% and the maximum coefficient of variation is 3.03% which meets the acceptance criteria of < 5%.

related_data.Title: Validation of an Automated Dispensing System for Radiopharmaceuticals According to GMP and GRPP Guidelines
related_data.Abstract: Automated dispensing systems (ADSs) for radiopharmaceuticals have been developed to reduce radiation exposure, improve dose accuracy, and limit microbiological contamination. This study presents the selection, validation, and implementation of the PT459R2 ADS for validation according to GMP and GRPP guidelines. Results show accurate dose dispensing for various isotopes within specific linear ranges, meeting acceptance criteria. The ADS maintains aseptic procedures, radiation exposure limits, and data integrity, making it suitable for routine use.
related_data.Institute of Origin: Department of Nuclear Medicine, Antoni van Leeuwenhoek, Amsterdam, The Netherlands
related_data.Funding: Not applicable
related_data.Methods: The study used the PT314R2 ADS placed in a GMP grade A microbiological safety cabinet. System validation included linear range, accuracy, and precision testing for different isotopes. Aseptic production validation involved environmental and production assessments. Radiation protection was evaluated by comparing theoretical and measured dose rates. Data integrity validation involved software communication testing.
related_data.Results: The ADS demonstrated accurate dose dispensing within specified linear ranges for various isotopes. Aseptic production validation showed compliance with GMP class A requirements. Radiation protection measures met acceptance criteria. Data integrity validation confirmed correct software communication.

Question_3771.Context: Condensed tannins (CTs) are secondary metabolites in plants that consist of oligomeric and polymeric flavan-3-ols subunits. These subunits include catechin, epicatechin, and their gallate derivatives, which have been shown to exhibit antibacterial activity.
Question_3771.Question: Which subunit of condensed tannins has drawn significant interest due to its strong ability to inhibit bacteria?
Question_3771.Source: Among these CTs, EGCG has drawn the most interest from microbiologists because it contains both galloyl and gallic moieties in flavan-3-ol units, resulting in EGCG having the strongest ability to inhibit bacteria.

related_data.Title: Antibacterial Mechanism of Condensed Tannins from Sainfoin Against Pediococcus pentosaceus
related_data.Abstract: The antibacterial mechanisms of action of condensed tannins (CTs) obtained from tea are well known. However, the antibacterial mechanism of CTs from legumes, such as sainfoin, against Pediococcus pentosaceus was still unclear. Using Pediococcus pentosaceus SF11 as a model organism, this study investigated the antibacterial mechanism of CTs (extract from sainfoin by 70% acetone aqueous solution). The results showed that CTs decreased the activities of enzymes such as lactic dehydrogenase, and inhibited the pentose phosphate (PP)/glycolytic pathway. The content of hydrogen peroxide produced by CTs was increased in P. pentosaceus SF11, and antibacterial activity partly occurred due to this hydrogen peroxide. The global transcriptome analysis showed that CTs upregulated the expression of 187 genes, most of which were involved in hypothetical protein, followed by the PTS (phosphotransferase system) system, while three genes were involved in oxidative stress.
related_data.Journal: Chemical and Biological Technologies in Agriculture
related_data.Institute of Origin: Shihezi University, China
related_data.Funding: National Natural Science Foundation of China (NSFC) (Grant No. 32060399) and the China Agriculture Research System of MOF and MARA (Grant No. CARS)
related_data.Methods: The study investigated the antibacterial mechanism of CTs against Pediococcus pentosaceus through determining the minimal inhibitory concentration (MIC) of CTs, effects of CTs on cell membrane, scanning and transmission electron microscopy analysis, and global transcriptome analysis.
related_data.Results: The results showed that CTs inhibited enzyme activities, increased hydrogen peroxide content, and upregulated gene expression related to hypothetical proteins and the PTS system.
related_data.Experiment details: The study used Pediococcus pentosaceus SF11 as a model organism and extracted CTs from sainfoin using a 70% acetone aqueous solution. Various experiments were conducted to investigate the antibacterial mechanism of CTs, including MIC determination, enzyme activity assays, hydrogen peroxide content analysis, and global transcriptome analysis.

Question_3772.Source: The mechanism of CTs against Pediococcus pentosaceus was investigated though determined the minimal inhibitory concentration (MIC) of CTs, effects of CTs on cell membrane, scanning and transmission electron microscopy analysis and global transcriptome analysis, et al.

Question_3777.Context: The phosphate ABC transporter system is a mechanism used by bacteria for the uptake of phosphate, which can be essential for various cellular processes.
Question_3777.Question: Which system involved in phosphate uptake in bacteria was found to be downregulated in response to condensed tannins?
Question_3777.Source: The expression of 161 genes was downregulated, most of which were involved in the phosphate ABC transporter system.

related_data.Title: Antibacterial Mechanism of Condensed Tannins from Sainfoin Against Pediococcus pentosaceus
related_data.Abstract: The antibacterial mechanisms of action of condensed tannins (CTs) obtained from tea are well known. However, the antibacterial mechanism of CTs from legumes, such as sainfoin, against Pediococcus pentosaceus was still unclear. Using Pediococcus pentosaceus SF11 as a model organism, this study investigated the antibacterial mechanism of CTs (extract from sainfoin by 70% acetone aqueous solution). The results showed that CTs decreased the activities of enzymes such as lactic dehydrogenase, and inhibited the pentose phosphate (PP)/glycolytic pathway. The content of hydrogen peroxide produced by CTs was increased in P. pentosaceus SF11, and antibacterial activity partly occurred due to this hydrogen peroxide. The global transcriptome analysis showed that CTs upregulated the expression of 187 genes, most of which were involved in hypothetical protein, followed by the PTS (phosphotransferase system) system, while three genes were involved in oxidative stress.

Question_3811.Context: Nicotiana glauca is a plant that can grow in suboptimal conditions and is known for producing a significant amount of biomass. It is a non-food crop that has been studied for its potential in biorefining applications.
Question_3811.Question: What family does Nicotiana glauca belong to?
Question_3811.Source: Nicotiana glauca (N. glauca) or the “tobacco tree” is a fast-growing shrub that belongs to the Solanaceae family.

related_data.Title: Evaluation of Nicotiana glauca as a Potential Feedstock for Biorefining
related_data.Abstract: The evaluation of plant-based feedstocks is an important aspect of biorefining. Nicotiana glauca, a non-food crop, was studied for its biomass potential and metabolite content. Sequential solvent extractions were applied to N. glauca leaves to enrich extracts containing various metabolites. The enriched fractions revealed high levels of hydrocarbons, oils, and co-products. Saccharification yield and cell wall composition analyses showed the potential of N. glauca as a lignocellulosic substrate for fermentable sugars production. The study presents a multifractional cascade for valuable compounds/commodities using N. glauca biomass.
related_data.Institute of Origin: Max-Planck-Institute of Molecular Plant Physiology, Royal Holloway University of London, Ghent University, Swiss Federal Institute of Technology Zurich, and others
related_data.Funding: The research leading to these results received funding from the European Union's Seventh Framework Programme and the BBSRC 21EBTA—Celfacto project.
related_data.Methods: The study involved large-scale extraction trials using ethanol and n-hexane to optimize extraction of polar and non-polar fractions. Metabolite profiling was performed using GC-MS and LC-MS. Quantification of solanesol and squalene was carried out. Saccharification analysis and cell wall composition studies were conducted. Micromechanical tests were performed on stem samples.
related_data.Results: The study identified a range of valuable compounds in N. glauca, including fatty acids, hydrocarbons, sterols, terpenoids, and sugars. The enriched fractions showed potential for biofuel, pharmaceutical, and industrial applications. The saccharification analysis demonstrated the potential of N. glauca as a feedstock for fermentable sugars production. Cell wall composition analysis and mechanical tests indicated the suitability of N. glauca for composite materials.
related_data.Experiment details: The study focused on the chemical characterization of N. glauca biomass and its potential for biorefining applications. The results highlight the diverse range of valuable compounds present in N. glauca and its suitability as a renewable feedstock. The extraction methods and analyses performed provide insights into the biorefining potential of N. glauca.

Question_3812.Context: In the process of evaluating plant-based feedstocks for biorefining, certain plants can be subjected to sequential solvent extractions to enrich the extracts with higher metabolite content.
Question_3812.Question: Which method was used to detect the occurrence of plant fatty acids, fatty acid alcohols, alkanes, sterols, and terpenoids in Nicotiana glauca?
Question_3812.Source: The occurrence of plant fatty acids, fatty acid alcohols, alkanes, sterols and terpenoids was detected by gas liquid chromatography–mass spectrometry (GC–MS) and metabolite identification was confirmed by comparison of physico‑chemical properties displayed by available authentic standards.
