related_data.Title: Evaluation of Nicotiana glauca as a Potential Feedstock for Biorefining
related_data.Abstract: The evaluation of plant-based feedstocks is an important aspect of biorefining. Nicotiana glauca, a non-food crop, was studied for its biomass potential and metabolite content. Sequential solvent extractions were applied to N. glauca leaves to enrich extracts containing various metabolites. The enriched fractions revealed high levels of hydrocarbons, oils, and co-products. Saccharification yield and cell wall composition analyses showed the potential of N. glauca as a lignocellulosic substrate for fermentable sugars production. The study presents a multifractional cascade for valuable compounds/commodities using N. glauca biomass.
related_data.Institute of Origin: Max-Planck-Institute of Molecular Plant Physiology, Royal Holloway University of London, Ghent University, Swiss Federal Institute of Technology Zurich, and others
related_data.Funding: The research leading to these results received funding from the European Union's Seventh Framework Programme and the BBSRC 21EBTA—Celfacto project.
related_data.Methods: The study involved large-scale extraction trials using ethanol and n-hexane to optimize extraction of polar and non-polar fractions. Metabolite profiling was performed using GC-MS and LC-MS. Quantification of solanesol and squalene was carried out. Saccharification analysis and cell wall composition studies were conducted. Micromechanical tests were performed on stem samples.
related_data.Results: The study identified a range of valuable compounds in N. glauca, including fatty acids, hydrocarbons, sterols, terpenoids, and sugars. The enriched fractions showed potential for biofuel, pharmaceutical, and industrial applications. The saccharification analysis demonstrated the potential of N. glauca as a feedstock for fermentable sugars production. Cell wall composition analysis and mechanical tests indicated the suitability of N. glauca for composite materials.
related_data.Experiment details: The study focused on the chemical characterization of N. glauca biomass and its potential for biorefining applications. The results highlight the diverse range of valuable compounds present in N. glauca and its suitability as a renewable feedstock. The extraction methods and analyses performed provide insights into the biorefining potential of N. glauca.

Question_3820.Context: In the study of plant metabolites, the relative abundance of compounds can be compared between different extraction methods to determine the most effective technique for compound recovery.
Question_3820.Question: Which fatty acid was found in higher recovery rates in the non-polar extract 1 compared to non-polar extract 2 of Nicotiana glauca?
Question_3820.Source: Other metabolites such as hexadecanoic acid, phytol, linoleic acid and lino- lenic acid, some isoprenoids and sterols such as squalene, stigmasterol, campesterol and β-sitosterol were also identified. Although most of the abundant compounds showed higher rela- tive abundances in non-polar extract 2, other metabolites such as tetracosan-1-ol showed improved recovery rates in non-polar extract 1.

Question_4041.Context: Radiohybrid PSMA-targeted ligands have been developed for theranostic applications in prostate cancer, aiming for optimized binding, reduced charge, and accelerated kidney excretion.
Question_4041.Question: What is the primary reason for developing radiohybrid PSMA-targeted ligands?
Question_4041.A: To increase the half-life of the ligands in the bloodstream
Question_4041.B: To provide an optimized binding profile to human serum albumin and accelerated kidney excretion
Question_4041.C: To enhance the visual contrast in imaging applications
Question_4041.D: To increase the overall negative charge of the ligands
Question_4041.Source: Radiohybrid PSMA-targeted ligands (rhPSMA) have been introduced as a novel platform for theranostic applications. Among a variety of rhPSMA-ligands developed for radioligand therapy, two stereoisomers [177Lu]Lu-rhPSMA-10.1 and -10.2 have been synthesized and initially characterized in preclinical experiments with the aim to provide an optimized binding profile to human serum albumin, a reduction of charge, and thus accelerated kidney excretion.

related_data.Title: Biodistribution and dosimetry of stereoisomeric radiohybrid PSMA-targeted radioligands in healthy and tumor-bearing mice
related_data.Abstract: Radiohybrid PSMA‑targeted ligands (rhPSMA) have been introduced as a novel platform for theranostic applications. Among a variety of rhPSMA‑ligands developed for radioligand therapy, two stereoisomers [177Lu]Lu‑rhPSMA‑10.1 and ‑10.2 have been synthesized and initially characterized in preclinical experiments with the aim to provide an optimized binding profile to human serum albumin, a reduction of charge, and thus accelerated kidney excretion, and unaffected or even improved tumor uptake. Our preclinical data on biodistribution and dosimetry indicate a more favorable profile of [177Lu]Lu‑rhPSMA‑10.1 compared to [177Lu]Lu‑rhPSMA‑10.2 for PSMA‑targeted radioligand therapy.
related_data.Institute of Origin: Technical University of Munich, Germany
related_data.Funding: Open Access funding enabled and organized by Projekt DEAL. HJW and ME receive funding from the SFB 824 (Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft, Bonn, Germany, Sonderforschungsbereich 824, Project B11 and Z).
related_data.Methods: General information, cell culture, animals and tumor xenograft model, radiolabeling procedures and quality controls, stability in vitro, biodistribution studies, dosimetry calculations, statistics.
related_data.Results: Radiochemistry and stability, biodistribution and dosimetry in non-tumor-bearing SCID mice, biodistribution and dosimetry in tumor-bearing mice, discussion.
related_data.Experiment details: The study focused on comparing the biodistribution and dosimetry of two stereoisomeric radiohybrid PSMA-targeted radioligands, [177Lu]Lu‑rhPSMA‑10.1 and ‑10.2, in healthy and tumor-bearing mice. The results indicated a more favorable profile of [177Lu]Lu‑rhPSMA‑10.1 for PSMA‑targeted radioligand therapy, showing fast kidney clearance kinetics resulting in excellent tumor-to-organ ratios over a therapy relevant time course.

Question_4042.Context: In the development of radioligand therapy, the pharmacokinetics of ligands are crucial, particularly their uptake and excretion rates in healthy versus tumor-bearing organisms.
Question_4042.Question: What is a desirable characteristic of a radioligand used in therapy for its pharmacokinetics?
Question_4042.A: High uptake and slow excretion from healthy organs
Question_4042.B: Low uptake and slow excretion from tumors
Question_4042.C: High uptake in tumors and fast clearance from healthy organs
Question_4042.D: Uniform uptake in both tumors and healthy organs
Question_4042.Source: As both isomers showed similar in vitro characteristics and tumor uptake at 24 h post injection in tumor bearing mice and in order to identify the isomer with the most favorable pharmacokinetics for radioligand therapy, we carried out in-depth biodistribution and dosimetry studies in tumor-bearing and healthy mice.

Question_4043.Context: Radiolabeled ligands are used in the detection and treatment of diseases, and their stability in various media is an important aspect of their effectiveness.
Question_4043.Question: Why is the stability of radiolabeled ligands in different media important?
Question_4043.A: To ensure they can be stored for long periods before use
Question_4043.B: To guarantee they maintain their charge in different environments
Question_4043.C: To ensure they remain effective during the time needed for diagnostic or therapeutic procedures
Question_4043.D: To increase their visibility under imaging techniques
Question_4043.Source: rhPSMA-10.1 and -10.2 were radiolabeled with lutetium-177 according to the established procedures of other DOTA-based PSMA ligands and displayed a high and comparable stability in all buffers and human serum (> 97%, 24 h).

Question_4044.Context: The use of stereoisomers in the development of radioligands can result in different in vivo behaviors, which is significant for their application in radioligand therapy.
Question_4044.Question: What impact can the stereoconfiguration of a radioligand have on its in vivo behavior?
Question_4044.A: It can change the color of the radioligand in imaging
Question_4044.B: It can affect the radioligand's stability in vitro only
Question_4044.C: It can influence the radioligand's binding characteristics and in vivo pharmacokinetics
Question_4044.D: It has no impact; all stereoisomers behave identically in vivo
Question_4044.Source: Distinctive differences were found in the kidneys, where [177Lu]Lu-rhPSMA-10.1 displayed lower initial uptake and faster excretion kinetics compared to [177Lu]Lu-rhPSMA-10.2 expressed by a 1.5-fold and ninefold lower uptake value at 1 h and 24 h in healthy animals, respectively.

Question_4045.Context: In radioligand therapy, the dosimetry studies involve calculating the radiation doses delivered to various organs to assess the potential risks and therapeutic benefits.
Question_4045.Question: What is the purpose of performing dosimetry studies in the context of radioligand therapy?
Question_4045.A: To determine the colorimetric properties of the radioligand
Question_4045.B: To calculate the radiation doses delivered to organs and tissues
Question_4045.C: To measure the electrical conductivity of the radioligand in tissues
Question_4045.D: To assess the magnetic properties of the radioligand
Question_4045.Source: For estimating tumor doses the unit density sphere model described by Stabin and Konijnenberg (2000) was utilized.

Question_4048.Question: Why is the kidney clearance rate of a radioligand important in its pharmacokinetic profile?
Question_4048.A: A faster clearance rate indicates higher toxicity to the kidneys

Question_4048.C: A faster clearance rate minimizes potential renal toxicity
Question_4048.D: The clearance rate has no impact on the pharmacokinetic profile
Question_4048.Source: Distinctive differences were found in the kidneys, where [177Lu]Lu-rhPSMA-10.1 displayed lower initial uptake and faster excretion kinetics compared to [177Lu]Lu-rhPSMA-10.2.

Question_4049.Question: What does a high tumor-to-organ ratio indicate in the context of radioligand therapy?
Question_4049.A: The radioligand is more toxic to healthy organs than to the tumor
Question_4049.B: The radioligand is non-specific and binds equally to tumors and healthy organs
Question_4049.C: The radioligand has a high specificity and potential efficacy against the tumor
Question_4049.D: The radioligand is likely to be rapidly excreted from the body
Question_4049.Source: [177Lu]Lu-rhPSMA-10.1 shows fast kidney clearance kinetics resulting in excellent tumor-to-organ ratios over a therapy relevant time course.

Question_4050.Context: The binding affinity of a radioligand to its target is a critical factor that influences its uptake in tumor cells and its effectiveness in radioligand therapy.
Question_4050.Question: Why is the binding affinity of a radioligand to its target important?
Question_4050.A: A higher binding affinity usually correlates with higher uptake in target cells and increased therapeutic effectiveness
Question_4050.B: A lower binding affinity is preferred to ensure rapid clearance from the body
Question_4050.C: Binding affinity is only relevant for imaging purposes and not for therapy
Question_4050.D: Binding affinity affects the color of the radioligand in imaging
Question_4050.Source: In a preclinical selection process of rhPSMA-7 isomers which are different in the stereoconfiguration of a Diaminopropionic acid unit (D-Dap or L-Dap) and the chelator (R-DOTAGA or S-DOTAGA), rhPSMA-7.3 (D-Dap, S-DOTAGA) displayed superior tumor uptake and faster clearance from background organs, compared with other isomers.

related_data.Methods: General information, cell culture, animals and tumor xenograft model, radiolabeling procedures and quality controls, stability in vitro, biodistribution studies, dosimetry calculations, statistics.
related_data.Results: Radiochemistry and stability, biodistribution and dosimetry in non-tumor-bearing SCID mice, biodistribution and dosimetry in tumor-bearing mice, discussion.
related_data.Experiment details: The study focused on comparing the biodistribution and dosimetry of two stereoisomeric radiohybrid PSMA-targeted radioligands, [177Lu]Lu‑rhPSMA‑10.1 and ‑10.2, in healthy and tumor-bearing mice. The results indicated a more favorable profile of [177Lu]Lu‑rhPSMA‑10.1 for PSMA‑targeted radioligand therapy, showing fast kidney clearance kinetics resulting in excellent tumor-to-organ ratios over a therapy relevant time course.

Question_4271.Context: Biliverdin is a bile pigment that is produced through the degradation of heme, a component of hemoglobin in red blood cells.
Question_4271.Question: What enzyme is responsible for the selective cleavage of heme to produce biliverdin?
Question_4271.Source: A selective cleavage of heme by heme oxygenase (HO; EC 1.14.99.3) occurs at the α-methane bridge, producing the biliverdin IXα isomer.

related_data.Title: Production of Biliverdin by Biotransformation of Hemin Using Recombinant Pichia pastoris
related_data.Abstract: Biliverdin, a bile pigment hydrolyzed from heme by heme oxygenase (HO), serves multiple functions in the human body, including antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and immune response inhibitory activities. Biliverdin has great potential as a clinical drug; however, no economic and efficient production method is available currently. Therefore, the production of biliverdin by the biotransformation of exogenous heme using recombinant HO-expressing yeast cells was studied in this research.
related_data.Institute of Origin: Zhejiang University of Technology
related_data.Funding: Key Research and Development Program of Zhejiang Province (2021C03088-2)
related_data.Methods: The plastid transit peptide sequence of the HO1 gene from A. thaliana was removed and the shortened coding sequence recombined into P. pastoris GS115. The cells of the recombinant GS115-HO1 P. pastoris were used to achieve the biotransformation of hemin into biliverdin. Following optimization studies, the yield of biliverdin was 132 mg/L when hemin was added to the GS115-HO1 culture.
related_data.Results: The conversion yield of biliverdin reached its peak after 4 h of biotransformation and then gradually decreased. The conversion yield of biliverdin was highest when 0.05 mol/L NaOH aqueous solution was used as the solvent for adding hemin to the culture.
related_data.Experiment details: The biotransformation was performed with a hemin concentration of 0.2 g/L, temperature of 30 °C, and shaking speed of 180 r/min. The conversion yield of biliverdin reached its peak after 4 h of biotransformation and then gradually decreased.

Question_4272.Context: Biliverdin can be reduced to another compound that is also part of heme metabolism in vertebrates.
Question_4272.Question: What is biliverdin reduced to in the human body?
Question_4272.Source: Biliverdin is subsequently reduced to bilirubin IXα by biliverdin reductase (EC 1.3.1.24).

Question_4279.Context: In the context of biotransformation, the efficiency of converting heme into biliverdin can be affected by the characteristics of the host organism.
Question_4279.Question: Why is it challenging for E. coli cells to achieve a high yield of biliverdin through biotransformation?
Question_4279.A: E. coli cells cannot synthesize heme
Question_4279.B: E. coli cells have a high rate of biliverdin degradation
Question_4279.C: E. coli cells cannot take up exogenous heme due to the absence of carrier proteins in its cell membranes
Question_4279.D: E. coli cells lack the necessary enzymes for biotransformation
Question_4279.Source: However, due to the limited ability of E. coli to synthesize heme, achieving a high yield of biliverdin by this route is challenging.

Question_4331.Context: In anaerobic digestion, hydrolysis and acidogenesis are often spatially separated from methanogenesis to improve the digestion of residual biomass.
Question_4331.Question: Which of the following is NOT a benefit of separating hydrolysis and acidogenesis from methanogenesis in anaerobic digestion?
Question_4331.A: Prevention of fast acidification of methanogenesis with easily degradable matter
Question_4331.B: Detoxification of inhibiting biomass such as citrus waste
Question_4331.C: Increased hydrolysis of recalcitrant biomass under certain conditions
Question_4331.D: Decreased overall yield of the digestion process
Question_4331.Source: The two-stage setup holds various advantages depending on the feedstock: (i) a fast acidification of the methanogenesis is prevented in case of a sudden increase of easily degradable matter (e.g., food waste), (ii) the detoxification of inhibiting biomass such as citrus waste (Lukitawesa et al. 2018) or inhibitors from thermal pretreatment (Li et al. 2017); (iii) increased hydrolysis of recalcitrant biomass in the first stage under certain process conditions (e.g., acidic or alkaline pH-value) other than optimal for full digestion (Voelklein et al. 2016; Cheah et al. 2019), (iv) thermophilic pre-digestion (Garcia-Aguirre et al. 2017; Qin et al. 2017), respectively.

related_data.Title: Spatial on‑line monitoring of gradient formation in plug-flow reactors during dynamic hydrolytic digestion
related_data.Abstract: Hydrolysis at changing hydraulic retention time, recirculation, bedding straw content in the feed, bioaugmentation and the impact of those changes on gradient formation in the liquid phase in plug-flow reactors (PFRs) was examined. The pH-value, conductivity and oxidation–reduction potential (ORP) were monitored at three spots along the PFRs to study potential correlations to process performance during a total process time of 123 weeks. The on-line monitoring showed good correlations to acidogenesis: namely, the pH and ORP to the acidification, to butyric (and lactic) acid concentration and to the acid yield. The ORP (measured at the inlet) showed the most stable correlation to acidogenesis under dynamic operation, while the conductivity (at the outlet) correlated to the acid concentration in dependence on the feedstock. Multiple measurement spots as used in this study allow to gain more information about acidogenic fermentation than a single spot, simplifying process control and automation attempts with recalcitrant feedstock.
related_data.Institute of Origin: Technische Universität Berlin, Germany; Aalborg University Esbjerg, Denmark
related_data.Funding: Fachagentur für Nachhaltige Rohstoffe e.V. (FNR), grant number 22039818
related_data.Methods: The study involved continuous operation of two parallel plug-flow reactors equipped with on-line sensors for pH-value, conductivity, and ORP. The process performance was evaluated by measuring metabolites and the physiological state of the mixed culture. Data evaluation and correlation analysis were conducted to identify relationships between on-line parameters and process performance.
related_data.Results: The study identified correlations between on-line measurements and acidogenesis, with the ORP measurement at the inlet showing direct correlations with acidification, butyric acid, and lactic acid concentrations. The on-line monitoring of conductivity at the outlet was found to be a reliable indicator for the accumulation of total short-chain carboxylic acids (SCCAs) in the PFR during dynamic operation conditions.
related_data.Experiment details: The experiment involved variations in hydraulic retention time, recirculation, and bioaugmentation while keeping the feedstock composition constant. The study demonstrated the robustness of on-line monitoring for detecting fermentation patterns and acid concentrations under changing process conditions.

Question_4332.Context: In anaerobic digestion, the hydrolytic and acidogenic microbial community is robust towards changes in environmental conditions, which offers flexibility in the AD system.
Question_4332.Question: What is a benefit of introducing a hydrolysis stage in anaerobic digestion systems?
Question_4332.A: Decreased flexibility of the AD system
Question_4332.C: Reduced stability of the AD system
Question_4332.Source: Since the hydrolytic and acidogenic microbial community is more robust towards changes in the environmental conditions, introducing a hydrolysis stage also offers a higher flexibility of the AD system, especially for the on-demand production of methane (Hahn et al. 2014; Linke et al. 2015).

Question_4333.Context: In the context of anaerobic digestion, electrochemical sensors are a method of monitoring that has been implemented frequently in pilot scale.
Question_4333.Question: Which of the following is a characteristic of electrochemical sensors used in anaerobic digestion monitoring?
Question_4333.A: They are generally too expensive for large scale use
Question_4333.B: They offer limited information compared to titration methods
Question_4333.C: They are a fast, convenient, and cheap method of monitoring
Question_4333.D: They are rarely implemented due to their complexity
Question_4333.Source: In contrast, electrochemical sensors are a fast, convenient, and cheap method of monitoring, that has already been implemented frequently in pilot scale (Wu et al. 2019; Cruz et al. 2021).

Question_4334.Context: Plug-flow reactors (PFRs) with laminar flow create gradients among pH-value, ORP, and conductivity due to radial mixing.
Question_4334.Question: What is a likely observation in plug-flow reactors (PFRs) with laminar flow during acidification?
Question_4334.A: Uniform distribution of pH-value, ORP, and conductivity
Question_4334.B: Gradients of pH-value, ORP, and conductivity
Question_4334.C: Complete absence of pH-value, ORP, and conductivity changes
Question_4334.D: Instantaneous mixing and equalization of pH-value, ORP, and conductivity
Question_4334.Source: In plug-flow reactors (PFRs) with laminar flow, mixing occurs in radial direction more or less exclusively. As a result, if there is sufficient hydrolytic and acidogenic activity among the microbial population, gradients should appear among the pH-value, ORP and conductivity.

related_data.Abstract: Hydrolysis at changing hydraulic retention time, recirculation, bedding straw content in the feed, bioaugmentation and the impact of those changes on gradient formation in the liquid phase in plug-flow reactors (PFRs) was examined. The pH-value, conductivity and oxidation–reduction potential (ORP) were monitored at three spots along the PFRs to study potential correlations to process performance during a total process time of 123 weeks. The on-line monitoring showed good correlations to acidogenesis: namely, the pH and ORP to the acidification, to butyric (and lactic) acid concentration and to the acid yield. The ORP (measured at the inlet) showed the most stable correlation to acidogenesis under dynamic operation, while the conductivity (at the outlet) correlated to the acid concentration in dependence on the feedstock. Multiple measurement spots as used in this study allow to gain more information about acidogenic fermentation than a single spot, simplifying process control and automation attempts with recalcitrant feedstock.
related_data.Institute of Origin: Technische Universität Berlin, Germany; Aalborg University Esbjerg, Denmark
related_data.Funding: Fachagentur für Nachhaltige Rohstoffe e.V. (FNR), grant number 22039818
related_data.Methods: The study involved continuous operation of two parallel plug-flow reactors equipped with on-line sensors for pH-value, conductivity, and ORP. The process performance was evaluated by measuring metabolites and the physiological state of the mixed culture. Data evaluation and correlation analysis were conducted to identify relationships between on-line parameters and process performance.
related_data.Results: The study identified correlations between on-line measurements and acidogenesis, with the ORP measurement at the inlet showing direct correlations with acidification, butyric acid, and lactic acid concentrations. The on-line monitoring of conductivity at the outlet was found to be a reliable indicator for the accumulation of total short-chain carboxylic acids (SCCAs) in the PFR during dynamic operation conditions.
related_data.Experiment details: The experiment involved variations in hydraulic retention time, recirculation, and bioaugmentation while keeping the feedstock composition constant. The study demonstrated the robustness of on-line monitoring for detecting fermentation patterns and acid concentrations under changing process conditions.

Question_4336.Context: In anaerobic digestion, the hydraulic retention time (HRT) is one of the process conditions that can be varied.
Question_4336.Question: Which of the following process conditions does NOT directly influence gradient formation in plug-flow reactors during anaerobic digestion?
Question_4336.Source: In particular, changes of the feedstock composition, the SCCA composition and bioaugmentation were found to influence the spatial gradient development in the PFRs. In contrast, variation of the HRT or thin-sludge recirculation did not provoke significant changes in the gradient formation.

Question_4337.Context: The pH-value in anaerobic digestion is an important parameter that can affect microbial activity and process performance.
Question_4337.Question: What effect does a higher pH-value generally have on the microbial hydrolysis of maize silage in anaerobic digestion?
Question_4337.B: It has no effect on the hydrolysis yield
Question_4337.D: It completely halts the hydrolysis process
Question_4337.Source: For MS, a higher pH-value was found to generally increase the hydrolysis yield. This is caused by the higher activity of hydrolytic microorganisms at less acidic pH-values (Azman et al. 2015).

Question_4338.Context: The presence of short-chain carboxylic acids (SCCAs) can influence the hydrolysis of lignocellulosic biomass in anaerobic digestion.
Question_4338.Question: How can the presence of SCCAs like acetic acid affect the hydrolysis of lignocellulosic biomass?
Question_4338.A: It can induce swelling and fragmentation of the biomass
Question_4338.B: It can completely degrade the lignocellulosic structures
Question_4338.C: It has no effect on the hydrolysis process
Question_4338.D: It can reduce the surface area available for enzymatic degradation
Question_4338.Source: The presence of SCCA, such as acetic acid, which accumulated during acidogenesis, has been demonstrated to induce swelling and fragmentation of lignocellulosic biomass. This process leads to an enlargement of the surface area and higher porosity, which subsequently exposes hemicellulose and cellulose to enzymatic degradation (Peng et al. 2019; Ma et al. 2021).

Question_4339.Context: In anaerobic digestion, the oxidation–reduction potential (ORP) can be used to monitor the fermentation patterns.
Question_4339.Question: What does an ORP measurement between -200 and -300 mV typically indicate about the fermentation pattern at the inlet of a plug-flow reactor?
Question_4339.Source: A low pH-value and higher ORP measurements at the inlet favor lactic acid fermentation, whereas a higher pH-value at the center combined with a low ORP at the inlet and outlet results in a dominant butyric acid fermentation.

Question_4340.Source: The monitoring of the conductivity, especially at the outlet, proved to be a reliable indicator for the accumulation of the total SCCAs, in both PFRs and under significant operational (HRT, recirculation) and microbial/process changes (bioaugmentation, variation in metabolism).

Question_4411.Question: Which reagent is commonly used as a coupling agent in esterification reactions?
Question_4411.Source: 1 was prepared by an esterification reaction in the presence of EDC as the coupling agent and a catalytic quantity of DMAP.

related_data.Title: Radiolabeling of ACooP with Fluorine-18 for FABP3-Targeted PET Imaging Applications
related_data.Abstract: Fatty acid binding protein 3 (FABP3) targeted ACooP peptide was successfully radiolabeled by S-acylation using 6-[18F]fluoronicotinic acid 4-nitrophenyl ester as the prosthetic compound. The tissue binding and blocking studies together with anti-FABP3 immunostaining confirmed [18F]FNA-S-ACooP binding specificity.
related_data.Institute of Origin: University of Turku, Turku PET Centre, Turku, Finland
related_data.Funding: This work was supported by [Funding Source].
related_data.Methods: The prosthetic compound 6-[18F]fluoronicotinic acid 4-nitrophenyl ester was prepared with an on-resin 18F-fluorination method. ACooP peptide was conjugated with [18F]1 using HPLC purification. LogD7.4 measurements were performed to determine the compound's hydrophilicity.
related_data.Results: The radiolabeled product [18F]FNA-S-ACooP exhibited high binding specificity in malignant tissue sections with FABP3 expression. In vitro tissue binding and autoradiography studies confirmed the specific binding of [18F]FNA-S-ACooP.
related_data.Experiment details: The synthesis of 6-[18F]fluoronicotinic acid 4-nitrophenyl ester and the conjugation of ACooP peptide were carried out following established procedures. Structural characterization of the radiolabeled product was performed using LC-MS and NMR techniques. Stability studies in rat plasma showed the integrity of [18F]FNA-S-ACooP.

Question_4412.Context: In peptide synthesis, protecting groups are often used to prevent certain reactions from occurring at specific sites on the amino acids.
Question_4412.Question: Which functional group on the ACooP peptide was unexpectedly targeted for acylation instead of the expected site?
Question_4412.Source: Interestingly, 6‑[18F]fluoronicotinic acid 4‑nitrophenyl ester conjugated to ACooP exclusively by S‑acylation instead of the expected N‑acylation.

related_data.Results: The radiolabeled product [18F]FNA-S-ACooP exhibited high binding specificity in malignant tissue sections with FABP3 expression. In vitro tissue binding and autoradiography studies confirmed the specific binding of [18F]FNA-S-ACooP.
related_data.Experiment details: The synthesis of 6-[18F]fluoronicotinic acid 4-nitrophenyl ester and the conjugation of ACooP peptide were carried out following established procedures. Structural characterization of the radiolabeled product was performed using LC-MS and NMR techniques. Stability studies in rat plasma showed the integrity of [18F]FNA-S-ACooP.

Question_4451.Context: Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a group of chronic disorders affecting the gastrointestinal tract, which includes conditions such as Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis. These diseases are characterized by inflammation of the gut, but the exact causes are not fully understood.
Question_4451.Question: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic feature of Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD)?
Question_4451.A: Chronic disorders of the gastrointestinal tract
Question_4451.B: Includes Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis
Question_4451.C: Caused by excessive production of digestive enzymes
Question_4451.D: Characterized by inflammation of the gut
Question_4451.Source: Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), including Crohn’s disease and ulcerative colitis, is a family of chronic disorders along the gastrointestinal tract characterized by its idiopathic and relapsing nature.

related_data.Title: Polymeric Nanozymes for Targeting Neutrophil Extracellular Traps in Inflammatory Bowel Disease
related_data.Abstract: In this research, polymeric nanozymes were fabricated to increase the delivery and therapeutic efficacy of DNase-I for the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). The nanozymes successfully alleviated various pathophysiological symptoms of IBD by attenuating neutrophil infiltration and NETosis in the colon.
related_data.Institute of Origin: Sungkyunkwan University (SKKU)
related_data.Funding: National Research Foundation of Korea, Korea Health Technology R&D Project, Korean Fund for Regenerative Medicine, Ministry of SMEs and Startups
related_data.Methods: The polymeric nanozymes were fabricated using PLGA core coated with dopamine and PEGylated to enhance stability and mucopenetration. Enzymatic activity was confirmed using a DNA degradation assay. In vitro cytotoxicity, stability, and NET-degrading ability were assessed.
related_data.Results: DNase-NZ treatment significantly inhibited body weight loss, reduced pro-inflammatory cytokine levels, and maintained colon structural integrity in DSS-induced colitis models. Neutrophil infiltration and NETosis were attenuated in the colon.
related_data.Experiment details: Mice were treated with DNase-NZ intra-rectally for 7 days following DSS-induced colitis. Body weight, colon length, disease activity index, cytokine levels, MPO activity, histological analysis, immune cell populations, and gene expression levels were evaluated.

Question_4452.Context: Neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) are structures composed of DNA and proteins released by neutrophils during inflammation. They are intended to trap pathogens but can also contribute to inflammation and tissue damage if not regulated properly.
Question_4452.Question: What is the role of neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) in the context of inflammation?
Question_4452.B: To capture pathogens and activate the immune system
Question_4452.Source: NETs are DNA-based extracellular structures released by activated neutrophils during inflammation to capture pathogens and further activate the immune system.

Question_4481.Context: Black carbon, also known as pyrogenic carbon, is a material produced by the incomplete combustion of organic matter in environments with limited oxygen supply. Its structure varies in aromaticity, ranging from slightly charred organic material to highly condensed aromatic compounds such as soot.
Question_4481.Question: What is black carbon also known as?
Question_4481.Source: Black carbon, also known as pyrogenic carbon, is formed by incomplete combustion of organic matter under limited oxygen supply.

related_data.Title: Assessment of Artificial Formation of Benzene Polycarboxylic Acids in Soil and Plant Samples during Black Carbon Analysis
related_data.Abstract: Black carbon is extensively studied in various environments due to its ubiquity. Different methods have been adopted for black carbon determination, among them using benzene polycarboxylic acids (BPCA) as molecular markers for the polycondensed aromatic moieties of charred materials. The aim of this work was to assess if artificial formation of BPCA occurs in soil samples when the organic carbon load exceeds 5–10 mg. Results show that for soil samples, no artificial BPCA formation occurred at least up to 20 mg of total organic carbon. However, for some plant samples, artificial BPCA formation occurred when more plant material equivalent to 10 mg total organic carbon was used.
related_data.Journal: Chemical and Biological Technologies in Agriculture
related_data.Institute of Origin: Martin Luther University Halle-Wittenberg, Germany
related_data.Funding: Open Access funding enabled and organized by Projekt DEAL. Funding was provided by Martin Luther University Halle-Wittenberg, Germany.
related_data.Methods: The study assessed the artificial formation of BPCA in soil and plant samples during black carbon analysis. Different methods were used including high-pressure digestion and microwave-assisted oxidation process. Samples were analyzed for BPCA content and black carbon content. Correlation analysis was performed to evaluate the relationship between sample weight and BPCA content.
related_data.Results: The results showed that no artificial BPCA formation occurred in soil samples up to 20 mg of total organic carbon. However, artificial BPCA formation was observed in plant samples when the organic carbon load exceeded 10 mg. The study also compared the conventional and microwave-assisted oxidation processes and found differences in BPCA content between the two methods.
related_data.Experiment details: The experiment involved analyzing soil and plant samples for BPCA content using different oxidation processes. The results highlighted the importance of sample weight in determining the occurrence of artificial BPCA formation. The study provided insights into the factors influencing BPCA formation during black carbon analysis.

Question_4482.Context: The chemical structure of black carbon increases in aromaticity from slightly charred material to highly condensed forms like graphite and soot. This gradation reflects the degree of combustion and the conditions under which the material was formed.
Question_4482.Question: Which form of carbon represents the highest degree of aromaticity in the black carbon continuum?
Question_4482.Source: Its chemical structure is characterized by increasing aromaticity from slightly charred material over char and charcoal to graphite and soot particle recondensed from the gas phase.

Question_4491.Context: L-type amino acid transporters (LAT1) are known to be overexpressed in various cancers and play a crucial role in cancer growth and survival. Radiohalogen-labeled amino acid derivatives that target LAT1 can be used for cancer imaging and radiotherapy.
Question_4491.Question: Which radiohalogen-labeled amino acid derivative exhibits instability against deastatination in vivo, posing a challenge for its use in radiotherapy?
Question_4491.Source: However, 211At-labeled amino acid derivatives exhibit instability against deastatination in vivo, making it challenging to use 211At for radiotherapy.

related_data.Title: Radiohalogen-labeled amino acid derivatives with high dehalogenation stability for cancer radiotheranostics
related_data.Abstract: L-type amino acid transporter 1 (LAT1) is overexpressed in various cancers, leading to the development of radiohalogen-labeled amino acid derivatives as promising candidates for cancer radiotheranostics. In this study, radiohalogen-labeled amino acid derivatives ([211At]At-NpGT, [125I]I-NpGT, and [18F]F-NpGT) were synthesized with high dehalogenation stability. The compounds were recognized as substrates of LAT1 in in vitro studies using C6 glioma cells. Biodistribution studies in C6 glioma-bearing mice showed high stability against in vivo dehalogenation and similar biodistributions. [211At]At-NpGT exhibited a dose-dependent inhibitory effect on tumor growth, suggesting promising applications in radiotheranostics.
related_data.Institute of Origin: Graduate School of Pharmaceutical Sciences, Chiba University, Japan
related_data.Funding: Grant-in-Aid for JSPS Fellows, Grant-in-Aid for Scientific Research (C) from JSPS, Global and Prominent Research, Chiba University, Innovative Medicine CHIBA Doctoral WISE Program
related_data.Methods: The synthesis of radiohalogen-labeled amino acid derivatives was performed using a triflate precursor compound in a 2-step reaction with radiochemical yields ranging from 30-40%. In vitro studies included cellular uptake, extracellular release, and inhibition assays. Biodistribution studies were conducted in tumor-bearing mice, and therapeutic studies evaluated the inhibitory effect on tumor growth.
related_data.Results: The radiohalogen-labeled amino acid derivatives showed high stability against dehalogenation, recognition as LAT1 substrates, and similar biodistribution in tumor-bearing mice. [211At]At-NpGT exhibited a dose-dependent inhibitory effect on tumor growth, indicating potential for radiotheranostic applications.
related_data.Experiment details: The study focused on the synthesis and evaluation of radiohalogen-labeled amino acid derivatives for cancer radiotheranostics. Detailed methods included synthesis procedures, in vitro cellular studies, biodistribution analyses, and therapeutic efficacy assessments.

Question_4492.Context: In the development of radiopharmaceuticals, the stability of the compound against dehalogenation in vivo is a critical factor. Radiohalogen-labeled amino acid derivatives have been synthesized with high dehalogenation stability for use in radiotheranostics.
Question_4492.Question: What is the primary reason for the instability of radiohalogen-labeled amino acid derivatives in vivo?
Question_4492.Source: However, 211At-labeled amino acid derivatives are unstable in vivo and undergo deastatination, reportedly owing to weak carbon-astatine bond strength.

Question_4493.Source: radiohalogen-labeled compounds using the NpG structure show high stability against dehalogenation in vivo owing to high steric hindrance and resistance to P450 metabolism.

Question_4498.Context: The uptake and release of radiolabeled amino acid derivatives by tumor cells are indicative of their transport dynamics and potential for use in radiotheranostics.
Question_4498.Question: What does the uptake and subsequent release of radiolabeled amino acid derivatives by tumor cells indicate?
Question_4498.A: Their inability to be transported into cells
Question_4498.B: Their transport dynamics and potential for radiotheranostics
Question_4498.D: Their lack of recognition by LAT1
Question_4498.Source: Cellular uptake of [211At]At-NpGT, [125I]I-NpGT, and [18F]F-NpGT by C6 glioma cells increased over time. Furthermore, these radiolabeled compounds were gradually excreted from the cells.
